PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 could be used to support the provision by the Commonwealth Government of funding, counselling, etc. for deliberately procured abortions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should amend the Sex Discrimination Bill so as to prevent it from being used in support of deliberately procured abortions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 44 citizens), Chaney (from 64 citizens), Crichton-Browne (from 105 citizens), Durack (from 386 citizens), Jack Evans (from 26 citizens), Lewis (from 131 citizens), Mason (from 60 citizens), Robertson (from 35 citizens) and Sibraa (from 463 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to
Undermine civil liberties and religious freedoms;
Entrench abortion funding and render liable to action hospitals, doctors and nurses who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations;
Deny to parents their rights to insist that the school ''community'' provide an environment conducive to the development, including the moral development of their children.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of the principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Sir John Carrick (from 15 citizens) and Sibraa (from 15 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows-
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilizing chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 71 citizens), Boswell (from 20 citizens), Elstob ( from 21 citizens) and Messner (from 144 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain elected representatives and officers of local governments in Australia shows that
General revenue grants to local government under personal income tax sharing entitlements have increased by 8.2 per cent in 1983-84 over 1982-83,
The inflation rate over the same period was 11.2 per cent,
The increase in grants to State Governments over the same period was 11.8 per cent,
Increased demands are being made on local government authorities to participate in Federal Government programs e.g. Community Employment Program,
The Labor Party made a pre-election commitment to allocate not less than the real value of the previous year's allocation in general revenue grants to local government.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government will amend the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act of 1976, to provide a real term minimum guarantee to Local Government general revenue sharing arrangements in 1983-84, and in future years.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Dame Margaret Guilfoyle (from 22 citizens), Martin (from 10 citizens ), Scott (from 13 citizens) and Teague (from five citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are concerned about foreign owned military bases on Australian territory and the entry into Australian waters and territory of foreign warships and aircraft carrying nuclear weaponry. And that the Australian Government should take an active and constructive role in the promotion of a nuclear-free world. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
1. Promote the expression of Australian sovereignty by legislating to bring foreign military bases on Australian territory under the control of the Australian Government.

2. Make it compulsory that the disclosure of weaponry carried by foreign warships and aircraft be given in confidence to the Australian Government prior to a request for entry. And that foreign warships and aircraft that carry nuclear weaponry be banned from Australian waters and territory.
3. Legislate for the cessation of all uranium mining in Australia and its subsequent export.

4. Urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to pose to the Governments of the United States and the Soviet Union that both countries agree to immediately halt the testing, production and further deployment of all nuclear weapons, missiles and delivery systems in a way that can be checked and verified by both sides.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, being parents and other persons concerned about the education of all children, sheweth that the present Government has commenced a Policy of reduction and eventual abolition in Government funding to independent schools. This policy has been adopted without an appropriate and reasoned consideration of the circumstances of those schools and the parents who choose to send their children to them. In particular the Government, in making its decision, has failed to take into account the impact on the State school system of an increased enrolment of students who otherwise would have attended independent schools in the event that Government funding had not been reduced or abolished. The change in policy overlooks the fact that the cost of educating a child in a government school is two to three times the cost to the tax-payer of educating the same child in an independent school.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled reverse the decision of the Government and reinstate funding on an equitable basis as has been the case in previous years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Church of Mary Queen of Peace
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
This petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth.
That the Church of Mary Queen of Peace Klaipeda, Lithuania was the only church permitted (by the Soviet authorities) to be built in post-war Lithuania.
That the church was built by the Catholic parishioners from their own resources and with support from overseas Christians.
That upon completion of the church building in 1960, the church was not allowed to be consecrated and, in 1961 was resumed by the State for purposes other than religious.

That this resumption of the church and the subsequent persecution and arrests of the local clergy and other christians is contrary to the spirit and the letter of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenant on Human Rights.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled request the Australian Government to communicate most strongly to the Government of the USSR the sympathy of the petitioners for the plight of the Lithuanian Christians and ask that the Church of Mary Queen of Peace be restored to the Catholics of Klaipeda for the practice of their religion without interference.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Scheyville Airport, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3. The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to R.A.A.F. Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands, and their unique adherent wildlife.
5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every child in Australia is entitled to government financial support for their education whether they attend government schools or non-government schools .

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that urgent consideration be given to a favourable decision for the continuation of Federal Government per capita grants payable in respect of all children in non-government schools at a rate calculated as a percentage of government standard costs at a level not less than that prevailing in 1983.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 132 citizens), Mason (from 25 citizens) and Sibraa (from 25 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: The petition from parents representing the government schools in New South Wales respectively showeth that:
1. They call on the Federal Government to re-affirm publicly that its primary obligation is to government schools.
2. They support the Federal Government's policy decisions which have reduced funding to wealthy private schools and which have broken the nexus between government and non-government school costs.
3. They endorse the Federal Government's opposition to the provision of a 'base grant' to all non-government schools.
4. They ask that the Federal Government create a general recurrent resource base which is adequate for government schools through the provision of increased recurrent funding.

5. They call upon the Federal Government to negotiate agreements with State/ Territory Governments which will ensure a planned program of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens, teachers and parents working in and for the interests of the pupils in government schools and colleges throughout Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. We deplore the unprincipled and self-interested attacks being orchestrated by minority sects and groups against the policies and person of the Commonwealth Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, the Hon. Senator Susan Ryan.
2. We fully support the Federal Government's actions in reducing funds for the wealthiest private schools, and in breaking the nexus between government and non -government school costs.

3. We endorse the Federal Government's principled opposition to the provision of 'base grants' to all non-government schools, as a positive step towards fulfilling their commitment of primary obligation to Australia's government schools.

4. We call upon the Federal Government however to recognise that its failure to create an adequate general recurrent resource base for government schools through providing increased recurrent grants, will undermine its own Special Programmes and thus frustrate its own stated educational objectives of greater equity and participation.

5. We support the Federal Government's stated policy of entering into direct negotiations for joint agreements on these grants with State/Territory Governments, to ensure a planned program of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Button (from 44 citizens), Gietzelt (from 153 citizens), Robertson ( from 144 citizens) and Zakharov (from 112 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Representation Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

We the undersigned citizens of Australia believe that there is no justification for increasing the size of the Parliament, and therefore humbly petition the Senate to reject the proposed Representation Act 1983 which provides for 36 more federal politicians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Casino in Canberra
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That they strenuously object to the proposal to license a Casino in Canberra, because of the clearly established connections between Casinos and organized crime.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should: Reject any legislation which authorises the operation of a Casino in Canberra.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to undermine civil liberties and religious freedom.
It could also be a means of undermining the traditional family structure of our nation.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
should delay the Bill and ask:
That the Government set up a Joint Parliamentary Committee to examine:-
(a) the implications of the UN Covenant for public policy, the extent of Australian commitments, responsibilities and accountability in terms of the Covenant;
(b) the full effects of the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 for public policy in giving effect to the UN Convention.
The Terms of Reference of the Joint Parliamentary Committee to be widely publicised and oral and written submissions sought from the interested organisations and individuals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth-

That currently discrimination in provision of work, in appointment to jobs and in promotion exists in Australia on particular grounds including, inter alia, grounds of race, ethnic origin, marital status, pregnancy, sex and/or sexual preference; and
That currently discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits is exercised against particular groups of individuals-in particular, against married women.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discimination in Commonwealth employment, in employment of individuals under federal awards, in employment of persons by statutory bodies and quasi- governmental organisations, and in employment of all persons in areas over which Commonwealth and Australian Capital Territory equal opportunity legislation should have jurisdiction; and
That appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits to all persons without regard to sex and/or marital status.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in parliament assembled:
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth government

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognize that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Social Security whether his attention has been drawn to the statements by the New South Wales Premier and Federal Australian Labor Party President concerning the assets test, and, in particular, his statement:

QUESTION.PARA: There are too many inequities and anomalies in the assets test . . . I think they've got to start all over again, frankly.

Does the Minister recognise the similarity between the approach advocated by Mr Wran and that advocated by the Opposition? In view of the widespread concern expressed by the Opposition, by Mr Wran, by the Government back bench, by pensioner organisations and, yesterday, by the Australian Council of Social Service, has the Minister finally seen the light and will the Government now agree to allow the legislation to lie on the table at least until Parliament resumes at the end of February so that further consideration can be given to the proposals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, my attention was not drawn to Mr Wran's statement; I picked it up in the newspapers over the weekend. Yes, I did read what Mr Wran had to say on a couple of occasions. I disagreed with what Mr Wran said. Mr Wran was basing his statements on what he saw and on what he had been informed were inequities in the proposed assets test in the treatment of New South Wales people as against others. As I pointed out outside this place, I think it can be easily demonstrated that Mr Wran has been misled and is wrong in this area. This is Federal legislation. It is legislation dealt with by the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party and the Federal Parliament.

ANSWER.PARA: I am surprised at the second half of Senator Messner's question in view of the fact that his Party, the National Party of Australia, the Australian Democrats and, I understand, Senator Harradine have said that they will move to defer until February 1984 consideration of this legislation in the Senate. That being so, I can count how many votes will favour deferral. I am aware that that will mean that the legislation will be deferred. I believe that is a pity but I am not at all concerned, nor is the Government concerned, that we will, over that time, be in the position where we in the Parliament and the people outside the Parliament can see exactly what the proposal is, and debate the exact details of the proposal rather than the supposed details which have been debated in the last few days by Mr Peacock. I have no reason to leave the legislation lying on the table. I would prefer not to. But, as the Opposition parties and Senator Harradine combined apparently are determined to do that, there is not much I or the Government can do about it. We accept that.

We believe that, after it is laid on the table and after this issue has been debated, people will realise, as do many pensioner organisations and other organisations concerned with the aged, that the introduction of an assets test is desirable. If any anomalies that they have claimed they have seen but which we believe are not there come to the fore, we are not rigid enough not to make changes under those circumstances. But we believe that the only way to get fairness, not only for the low income pensioners but also for the taxpayers of this country, is to consider, in any means test, the assets holdings of individuals in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Social Security advise whether the Government will soon undertake a publicity campaign regarding the proposed pensions assets test? If so, what form will the campaign take and for what period will it run? Does the Minister anticipate that there will be on-going community liaison at least until the assets test legislation is passed?

—I believe that there will be plenty of publicity about the assets test, as there has been. I am not concerned about that. Certainly in the period between when the legislation is passed and when such a test would be introduced, we would of course conduct a publicity campaign to explain to the pensioners of this country how they would be affected, probably also how they would not be affected and how the assets test is to be introduced. That is standard procedure on the introduction of any new legislation. I assure honourable senators, and Senator Elstob in particular, that any such campaign will be effective, will be economical and will not be the party political campaign which was run by the previous Government after the Budget last year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Social Security whether he recalls writing in Labor Essays:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . to be consistent, those who argue for a pensions assets test should also argue for the personal income tax to be supplemented by a substantial tax on personal assets-in other words, a wealth tax.

Will the Minister now inform the Senate when the Government intends to follow the introduction of an assets test by the implementation of a wealth tax, be it in the form of a capital gains tax so strongly advocated by Senator Button or the gains tax and national death duties combination demanded by the Caucus Industry Committee Chairman, Dr Theophanous? If the Government does not intend to introduce a general wealth tax, does the Minister agree that the proposal for an assets test alone amounts to a selective capital gains tax on the aged?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indeed flattered that Senator Bjelke-Petersen has read my contribution to Labor Essays even if she has read only the bits she quoted. I am also flattered that she believes that anything she interprets from what I have written in Labor Essays will be automatically translated into government policy or Australian Labor Party policy.

ANSWER.PARA: I point out to the good senator that I am no stranger to selective quoting in this place; I have occasionally been guilty of that. That is what Senator Bjelke -Petersen is guilty of, if indeed she has read any more of the essays than the small section she quoted, which I note was exactly the section which was quoted by Senator Messner in a speech to the Voice of the Elderly last week.

What that essay is about is the myths and the reality of social security and social welfare expenditure in the community. It talks about the inequities of the system which existed whereby people could take lump sum superannuation and be taxed on only 5 per cent. It talks about the various aspects of social welfare expenditure and the revenue forgone in other areas of taxation expenditure in this community. It talks about the need for reform.

The section to which the good senator referred talks of course about those people who suggest-I am not one of them-that all one has to do to solve the inequities in our system is to introduce an assets test and nothing else. The Government does not believe that either. That is why the Government has a series of reforms in this area which will result in a higher base rate pension, which will result in better benefits for the pensioners in particular and for other disadvantaged people in our community.

So the answer is in fact no, it does not mean that the Labor Government is about to introduce a wealth tax. Nor does the article suggest that that is the way we should proceed. That article is a description of the system as it existed and the system as it may exist in the future. We do not shut off any options, but there is certainly no intention on the part of the present Government to introduce a general wealth tax in the community. To describe an assets test as a selective wealth tax on the aged is nonsense. I believe that Senator Bjelke- Petersen, if she thinks about it, will realise that it is nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. It concerns the advertising by one of the statutory authorities under the Minister's control-the Health Insurance Commission-and its selling of the service provided by Medibank Private. I was appalled to hear on radio an advertisement which tells people that they will be dealt with by a 'friendly girl with a computer'. How can we expect private advertisers to eliminate sexist advertisements if a government instrumentality keeps using them? Is it really true that the HIC employs only women to operate computers? If so, why? Even if it is so, why must the Commission perpetuate the offensive use of the diminutive 'girl', which is offensive even when what is meant is young women, and, even more so, when the women concerned are no longer young? Will the Minister ask the Minister for Health to ensure that the advertisement with that wording is withdrawn?

—I have not heard the advertisement referred to by Senator Coates, nor have I had my attention drawn to any similar advertisement. Like him, I would be concerned that a statutory authority of that type indulged in the sort of sexist advertising to which he referred. But I am aware also that the advertising for Medicare is, as I understand it, contracted out to private organisations, and sexist advertising of that type in our community is extremely common, as was demonstrated last week, I believe, by the Family Planning Association on Family Planning Day. I shall certainly draw the attention of the Minister for Health, who I am sure will be as appalled as is Senator Coates, to that sexist advertising and the use of the diminutive 'girl' in those circumstances and see whether statutory authorities of this type can show a better example in the future.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the welcome and proper criticism by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, of the Goa Declaration of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting because it did not deal adequately with the spread of nuclear weapons beyond those countries that presently have them. Does not the provision of nuclear technology to Third World nations include the know-how, the materials and the 'innocent' cover that enables them to build nuclear bombs, as was the case with India and Pakistan? Is the Minister aware that past Australian governments have sought to export our uranium to nations which have the most notoriously immoral leaders in the world, such as Iran and the Philippines, and that this Government is seeking to continue this lunatic practice with its negotiations with leaderships such as that of South Korea? How does the Government reconcile Mr Hawke's concern at an international forum for nuclear proliferation in Third World nations with his domestic zeal for exporting Australian uranium to such dubious customers?

—I am not at all sure that this is a matter for the Minister for Foreign Affairs but I shall certainly draw it to his attention and to the attention of the Minister for Trade and the Minister for Resources and Energy, who I think also comes into this matter but who is away at present. No doubt the Prime Minister himself would relish the opportunity to respond to some of Senator Chipp's suggestions. I simply make the point that the terms and conditions of any continuing exports of Australian uranium are very much the centrepiece of the proposed inquiry to be conducted by Professor Slatyer over the next few months because of the concern that the Government shares, along with Senator Chipp, for a number of the matters that Senator Chipp has mentioned . Pending the outcome of that inquiry, it would be inappropriate for me to comment further, although the other Ministers I have mentioned may well wish to do so.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism. I refer the Minister to allegations made by Raelene Boyle in her book Rage Raelene Run to the effect that the former Liberal Government paid off Australian athletes so that they would not participate in the Moscow Olympics. Did the then Government attempt to assume a high moral position on the boycott of the Moscow Olympics and do these allegations indicate that this position was both fraudulent and corrupt? Was there any truth in these allegations-
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. I draw your attention to the use of the word 'corrupt'. I would say that it is unparliamentary and should be withdrawn.
—There is no point of order. It was referred to in the generality. I call Senator Bolkus.

—With Senator Chaney's leave, I further ask the Minister whether there is any truth in these allegations. Has any young Australian athlete had his or her amateur status compromised by these bribes? Finally, will the Australian Government investigate the conduct and the alleged illegality of the conduct entered into by the then Government to see whether any charges can be laid?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, John Brown, has provided me with some information on this. The Government is aware that payments were made to sporting bodies and individuals who withdrew from participation in the Moscow Olympics. Such payments were allowed for in the Fraser Budget of 1980 -81. Although both the then Treasurer and the present Leader of the Opposition have recently commented in the media that they cannot recall the payments, a record of their having been made is available. However, the honourable member for Grayndler, as Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, yesterday highlighted some strangeness in relation to the payments made to various athletes. For the information of honourable senators I list the payments: Equestrian, $125,000; yachting, $52,840; men's hockey, $90,375; boxing , $13,784; women's hockey, $45,740; volleyball, $120,000; shooting, $41,000; and then a series of payments of $6,000 to individual athletes; totalling $524,738.

ANSWER.PARA: The facts speak for themselves and are an obvious indictment of the discredited Fraser Government which, while appearing to take a high minded moral attitude at the time, in fact has embarrassed these young athletes and brought the whole matter of amateur status in sport into some question. It is indeed unfortunate that, like so many other areas in our society, sport has had to suffer such undignified behaviour on the part of the previous Government. It is the case that some sporting commentators have noted that the Fraser Government may have placed the amateur status in jeopardy by paying money to individual sports men and women instead of paying it through their respective sporting organisations. The Australian sporting community can rest assured, however, that this Government will not use sport as a political football and that it is committed, as is evidenced by the record levels of funding in the first Hawke Budget, to support Australian sports men and women in a real and above-board fashion.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Is it a fact that one of the main justifications used by the Minister in introducing an assets test was to stop avoidance of the existing income test in order to direct a greater proportion of resources to those in need? Is it true that in a certain essay the Minister said of the previous assets test-similar to the one sought by his Government: 'It allowed considerable scope for manipulation of affairs'? How can the Minister therefore assure the Senate that such avoidance will cease under the assets test now proposed and that the needy will correspondingly benefit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the previous assets test was abolished the Government at the time claimed that it was in fact a no cost option. In fact the cost in the first year, from memory, was in excess of $100m. I cannot be held to it but I think it was $140m. Since then there has been an increasing and expanding industry of organisations which have established property trusts and other forms of circumvention of the income test. That industry has burgeoned in recent years so that one cannot help but see all the advertisements in the financial Press, in such newspapers as the National Times and all the newspapers in the country, aimed at retired people. As a result of that, clearly a considerable number of people quite legally have circumvented the income test so that the cost to the taxpayer at the moment is considerably higher than it was when that assets test was first removed in 1976.

ANSWER.PARA: Unless one introduces an assets test which incorporates every form of asset there will be an opening for some people in a very limited way to put money in certain directions and avoid that test. We believe that in the assets test we are proposing that is minimised. We are not saying it is a perfect system any more than any other system is perfect. We know that as a result of the assets test a considerable amount of money will be available. That money will be redistributed to those pensioners and beneficiaries who for the last seven years have seen their benefits eroded because of the inability and the failure of the previous Government to maintain the base rate of pension and benefit. They have seen their benefits eroded in such areas as extra pensions for children where, again, the level of that pension has been eroded by inflation and the failure of the previous Government to raise it. One of the reasons that the previous Government could not raise the level of pension was that never at any stage was it willing to do anything about the circumvention of which it was perfectly aware. We are willing to do so. We know that we will therefore be able to redistribute those funds to the benefit of those who really need them. We know that there will be general community acceptance of this.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Attorney-General indicate whether there are any legal implications in an Australian Premier declaring his State a country? I refer to an article in yesterday's Daily Sun, in which the Queensland Premier said of people transferring from interstate:

QUESTION.PARA: We cannot keep them out of our country. They are coming up here by the thousands.
Does the Attorney-General consider that such a statement challenges the Constitution and the right of all Australians to move freely from one State to another?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that there are any legal implications but there would appear to me to be some medical ones in that assertion made by the Premier. It is of course, not the case that Australia is anything other than a single country and it is the case that freedom of movement between the States is expressly guaranteed by the notorious-indeed, in this respect it deserves to be less notorious or less ill-favoured-section 92 of the Constitution which provides that not only trade and commerce between the States should be free but so too should intercourse between the States. There is a wartime legal precedent establishing very clearly that any constraints at all imposed at the border in respect of free movement are quite unconstitutional. So the answer to Senator Reynolds's question without notice is yes, it is quite a silly statement for the Queensland Premier to be making for all those reasons.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to reports that the Government's uranium decision has blocked negotiations on contracts to supply uranium worth more than $500m to three United States power utilities, which reports are based on information provided by Mr Gerry Hand, MP, to the special Victorian conference of the Australian Labor Party last Sunday. I ask the Leader of the Government whether it is a fact that three such contracts were blocked by that decision? I ask him on what basis was the content of a Cabinet submission, from which the information was obtained , made available to Mr Hand? Was Mr Hand authorised to reveal that information to the ALP conference and was confidential commercial information made available to Mr Hand?

—The Government's decision in relation to uranium mining is quite clear and has been stated on several occasions. Two contracts have been approved in respect of the Ranger project. There are existing contracts in respect of both Ranger and Nabarlek and the Commonwealth Government has granted permission for the Roxby Downs, or Olympic Dam, mine to proceed. That means, in terms of the Commonwealth's powers, permission for the Roxby Downs partners to negotiate export contracts. Further, the Government has indicated that no further mines shall be opened and that no further contracts will be let pending at least the report of the Slatyer inquiry. That position is quite clear and there can be no doubt about that answer in terms of the specifics which Senator Chaney addressed to me. I do not know whether three United States contracts, as a result of that statement-
—Don't you read your Cabinet submissions?

—The honourable senator asks me whether I read the Cabinet submissions. I do not recall reading that one. The fact of the matter is that I am unable to say with authority that three such contracts have been aborted as a result of that policy. I am quite unable to say whether the information allegedly revealed by Mr Gerry Hand at the Victorian ALP conference-
—He did reveal it, didn't he?

—Just let me finish the sentence. I am quite unable to reveal from what source the information made available by Mr Gerry Hand at the Victorian conference came. I am not able to say that. Certainly no member of the Parliament was authorised to make a statement and reveal information based on a Cabinet submission which was confidential.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Leader of the Government for his partial answer. I ask him whether he could perhaps read the Cabinet submission and, in particular, answer the part of the question left unanswered, namely, whether confidential commercial information was made available to Mr Hand. Could he check the facts to find out the source of the information which was given by Mr Hand and which was reported to be from the confidential Cabinet submission which was supposedly available only to members of the Government?

—The question whether confidential commercial information was available to Mr Hand is one which implies that there is some knowledge of the source. If Mr Hand had confidential commercial information, as far as I understand, it was certainly not provided by any member of the Government.
—Will you check that?
—I am then asked, as a second part of the question, whether I will check the source of Mr Hand's information. I am quite prepared to do that; and I will ask Mr Hand myself.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Has the Attorney-General seen the article headed 'Mock Tourist Map Angers Blacks', incorporating a racist map of the Ayers Rock area, which appeared in the Adelaide Advertiser on 18 November? What can be done through legislation or by other means to restrict the publication of such material? Are any remedies presently available for the victims of this type of publication?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the newspaper reports and descriptions of the mock tourist map in question and, indeed, the graphic representation of it in the newspaper article in question. I say straight away that I find it contemptible and disgusting, as I believe any honourable senator would. As to the question of what can be done about it, there is no prohibition on the dissemination of race hatred propaganda of this kind-it can only be so described -under the law as it now stands. An attempt was made by the previous Labor Government to introduce such a clause in the Racial Discrimination Bill, as it then was in 1974, but it was felt, after debate in this place, that competing considerations of free speech militated against that. I think that is a debate that we will have to have again in the near future, in the context of the revision of the Racial Discrimination Act which is now proceeding. As I have previously announced, a task force is working on this legislation. The debate will be much assisted by the report which has just arrived on my desk from the Human Rights Commission on the whole question of race hatred propaganda. I hope that the report will be printed and tabled in this place if not next week, certainly before we get up.

ANSWER.PARA: The matters in issue here are ones which have been canvassed briefly before. I do so only in one sentence again now, namely, whether or not we have some form of criminal prohibition on this kind of activity or whether we create some civil remedy lying by way of redress and an injunction or some right of correction or apology by way of some extension of the law of defamation in the context of group defamation. The third alternative is, of course, as always, to do nothing at all. I simply indicate to honourable senators that these are difficult questions which we will need to be addressing and debating early next year.
There could be very few more graphic demonstrations of the need for some kind of remedial action to be available in this area than the particular map, so described, to which Senator Maguire referred.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Leader of the Government in the Senate agree with the Leader of the Opposition in the Northern Territory, Mr Collins, that members of the Victorian Branch of the Australian Labor Party are 'ratbags and mindless political thugs' in their attitude towards uranium policy? If he does not share that view, does he believe that he and other members of Caucus who voted for the Government's Cabinet recommendation on uranium ratted on Labor policy, as claimed by Mrs Joan Coxsedge at Sunday's special State conference on uranium?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course I would not agree with the description used by my very good friend Bob Collins, the Leader of the Australian Labor Party in the Northern Territory, that people who take a different view from the view which he takes about uranium mining in the Northern Territory are ratbags and mindless political thugs. Bob Collins is an earthy type of chap. I am much more urbane and I would not use that sort of terminology about any of my Party colleagues in the way in which he did.

ANSWER.PARA: Insofar as I am asked to comment on the suggestion from Mrs Joan Coxsedge, a member of the Labor Party in the State of Victoria, that members of the Parliamentary Party ratted on that policy, namely, the Labor Party platform in relation to uranium, I do not agree with that view at all. In fact, I seldom find myself in agreement with any views expressed by Mrs Coxsedge. That is one of the great benefits of belonging to a pluralist and versatile party such as the Labor Party.

I believe that the platform of the Labor Party, as adopted at the 1982 Conference, had one substantial weakness in it, and that is that various sections of the Party left the 1982 Conference with the belief that the platform adopted there supported their particular position. There is no doubt that the South Australian Government, as it now is, thought that the--

TALK.START.PARA: —Tweedledum and Tweedledee?

—That is right, Senator. That is why the issue has been resolved. I would not agree with the view expressed by Mrs Coxsedge that members of the Parliamentary Labor Party, voting in support of the Government decision, ratted on that policy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Attorney-General whether he has seen an item in the National Times headed 'Spare the rod' which reads:

QUESTION.PARA: Senator Flo Bjelke-Petersen had some down-to-earth advice recently for the husbands of the women demonstrating at Pine Gap. She told a meeting of the Kirra -Currumbin Rotary Club on the Gold Coast that the women 'are most unbecoming in the way they are behaving and their husbands should give them a good strapping'.

Can the Attorney-General comment on whether this remark is, one, unbecoming and, two, a direct inducement to men to practise domestic violence? Can he indicate the size of the problem of domestic violence and its cost both to the community and to the women concerned? What steps have been taken to cope with the problems of domestic violence, in particular under the recent family law amendments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The remarks attributed to Senator Bjelke-Petersen do, as Senator Grimes was suggesting sotto voce, summon up a fascinating picture of life at Kingaroy. My picture is that of the Premier shuffling in and out of the family cave with a club in one hand and Senator Bjelke-Petersen's perm in the other. No wonder the dog bit him.
—The dog died.

—I am indebted to Senator Colston for that gloss. I do not have readily to hand figures on the size of the problem of domestic violence in this country and the cost of it. I hope that those figures will not be expanded by the example of leadership that has been given to us. I can, however, say that the Government, of course, does deplore this phenomenon no matter who the perpetrators or victims of it are, and has been trying to do something about it. In particular, I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that an amendment contained in the Family Law Amendment Act, which became effective last Friday, does increase the protection provided to children and spouses who are subjected to or threatened with physical violence in the domestic environment.

ANSWER.PARA: The new law, honourable senators may recall-they spent some considerable time debating it if not this section-will permit a power of arrest to be attached to an injunction granted for the personal protection of a child or spouse. We believe that the court should be able to attach a power of arrest order to an injunction not only where violence has already been committed but also where violence has been threatened. The legislation now so provides. This will require a continued co-operative effort between the Commonwealth and the States to resolve it properly. But to the extent that it is within the Commonwealth's capacity to do so, we have amended the law.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Resources and Energy aware that the Aboriginal traditional owners of Koongarra and Jabiluka uranium deposits have rejected the Government's uranium decision and want mining to proceed? Is he further aware of a reported assurance given by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to the Koongarra and Gagudju people that, if Roxby Downs went ahead, Koongarra and Jabiluka would automatically follow suit? Can he say whether Mr Holding's statement at Sunday's special Victorian Australian Labor Party Conference that 'Pancontinental is gone, Koongarra is gone' is an accurate statement of the present state of Government policy? If so, is Mr Holding guilty of misleading Aboriginal people whose interests he is supposed to support?

—Senator Crichton-Browne has erected an extraordinary intellectual edifice which I propose to topple, if I may. First of all, I am aware that Aboriginals have rejected the Government's policy in relation to Jabiluka and Koongarra. Secondly, I am not aware of any statement by Mr Holding made to the Aboriginal people that if Roxby Downs went ahead Jabiluka and Koongarra would also go ahead. I must say I think it unlikely that the Minister made any such statement. The date and authority for the suggestion that the Minister made that statement were not, of course, included in the question.
—Only just unlikely?

—Yes, just unlikely. I am not going to put my foot on Senator Teague's silly little block. The third part of the question is, of course, dependent on the second part; that is to say, if the Minister did say that to the Aboriginal people, how does that relate to the statements which Mr Holding is reported to have made at the special conference of the Victorian Branch of the Australian Labor Party last Sunday? I do not know what Mr Holding said at that conference but I think it is quite likely that he said the things that Senator Crichton-Browne quoted him as saying because they are consistent with the policy announcement which has been made by the Government in relation to mines such as Koongarra and Jabiluka.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware of the Queensland Government's decision to misrepresent deliberately the level of Medicare funding to Queensland? Will the Minister clarify the true level of Medicare payments to Queensland and reassure Queenslanders that they are not being short-changed by this unfair comparison with other States?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems that Mr Bjelke-Petersen and his colleagues are treating the truth in the way that Senator Evans implied that Mr Bjelke-Petersen may be treating his wife. He is, as usual, selectively quoting figures to present a case which is just not true. He claims that the Queensland Government and therefore the Queensland people are being robbed but he does not mention, of course, any of the advantages to Queensland of Medicare, particularly the advantages to individual Queenslanders. Only 42 per cent of Queenslanders have insurance to cover them for doctors' services compared with 65 per cent of people in the other States.
—They get it for nothing.

—I am amazed to hear someone like Senator Boswell say that anything costs nothing in this community. He and his colleagues are usually making speeches about how people do not get anything for nothing. The Medicare program, in fact, will spend an extra $150m on medical benefits in Queensland to provide cover for every Queenslander. This means that they will be able to see their local doctors or specialists rather than queue for hours in the out- patient clinics of local hospitals.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question of funding of Queensland's public hospitals, in a full year, under Medicare, Queensland will receive $173m, which is an 86 per cent increase on the funding provided in the last Fraser Budget. All other States have been compensated only for the revenue they lose by removing charges in public hospitals. So they are not in an overall better financial position. Queensland is the only State which receives a special grant-in this case it is $35m- actually to improve its health funding situation. This grant ensures that Queenslanders receive more in increased medical benefits, increased grants to private and public hospitals and increased funds for community health than they pay into Medicare through the one per cent levy on income and reduced reinsurance subsidies to private funds. Queensland pays $212m in a full year and receives $220m in increased benefits.

A more serious matter to Queenslanders, however, is that if the Queensland Government is threatening to use the $35m special health grant to fund other election promises and not to improve health services, quite clearly the Federal Government will have to look at making the $35m a specific purpose grant to ensure that it is used properly. The absolute hypocrisy of the Bjelke-Petersen Government's position is shown by the fact that the Fraser Government cut Queensland's health funding from $194m in 1980-81 to $93m in 1982-83. There were no High Court of Australia actions, no television advertising and no newspaper advertising at that time. The Fraser Government and the Bjelke-Petersen Government came to an agreement at the 1981 Premiers Conference to ensure that Queensland received a fair deal. Mr Bjelke-Petersen knows that Commonwealth- State financial agreements are complex. He ensured that if Queensland missed out on identified health grants it would more than pick those up in an increased share of the tax revenue.

The Medicare grants will benefit Queens- landers considerably. They will benefit not only financially but also by having access to a better health system and an improved system of public hospitals. Mr Bjelke-Petersen and most members of his Government know this. All the advertisements and the propaganda referred to by Senator Jones are simply lies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate aware that an increasing number of Labor Party members are looking to the Australian Labor Party national conference next year to decide finally whether or not the Caucus decision on uranium has any real standing? Does he share the view of the Minister for Territories and Local Government who, in a letter to the Sydney Morning Herald last week, said that the anti-uranium movement 'will not come to a standstill because of some temporary setback'? Given the disagreement of the Victorian Branch and the Western Australian Branch and the likely disagreement of the Queensland Branch of the Australian Labor Party with the uranium decision , what confidence can Australians have that the caucus policy favouring the Roxby Downs development will hold?

—I have great confidence that the decisions of this Government in respect of all matters will hold. It is a confidence shared by a number of prominent businessmen, including Mr Brian Kelman, who said to United States businessmen at a lunch in New York on Friday that this has been a very successful government, even from a businessman's point of view. I think that most of those involved in the resource-based industries are businessmen. I was asked whether I was aware that people in the Australian Labor Party are looking towards the next national conference for some reason or another.
—Businesses particularly.

—I do not think that many business people in the Labor Party are looking towards the national conference for any particular reason. The only reason would be for better legislation in the areas of consumer affairs and trade practices. I do not believe there are any strongly held anticipations about the next national conference. I suppose the purpose of the honourable senator's question was to try to undermine confidence in the Government's decisions. I fully understand that. Senator Walters suggested that the Minister for Territories and Local Government wrote a letter to the Sydney Morning Herald last week on this topic in certain terms. I am quite unaware of what the Minister said in his letter, but let me say this: In the context of the Australian Labor Party's discussion on this matter, the Minister for Territories and Local Government voted for a proposition which would have ensured the continuation of the Ranger mine and the Nabarlek mine. In those circumstances, I think it is unlikely that anybody ought to be concerned in the way in which Senator Walters suggests.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CHILE: OVERTHROW OF THE ALLENDE GOVERNMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Attorney-General aware that on 19 November in the Four Corners program suggestions were made that Australian intelligence had played a significant role in the overthrow of the Allende Government in Chile in 1973? What, if any, information is the Government able to give about the truth or otherwise of these allegations?

—It is the case that, on the Four Corners program which went to air on 19 November, in an interview with a former Minister for Labor and Immigration, Clyde Cameron, the clear impression was conveyed that Australian intelligence had played a role in the overthrow of the Allende Government in 1973, with particular reference being made to the alleged role of Australian Security Intelligence Organisation officers operating overseas as part of the establishment of the Department of Labor and Immigration. There are obvious constraints, which I have expressed in this chamber on previous occasions, on the extent to which one can or should ever depart from the principle of 'no comment' in these matters. I believe the circumstances of this case are exceptional, involving as they do, public statements by a former Minister of the Crown with apparent personal knowledge of the events in question. Accordingly, I believe it is appropriate to make the following short statement, which I will not further amplify inside or outside this Parliament. I hope this statement will do something to clarify the situation.

—I rise on a point of order. It is quite clear that there has been notice of this question. The Minister is using Question Time to make a statement on this matter. I pick up his own words. I would suggest that if the Minister wants to make a statement on this very sensitive subject it should be done in the form of a statement which would be open for debate. I also raise the point of order to give the Attorney-General a chance to stop and think before he puts his foot on the slippery slope again.
—It is not a statement in the sense of being anything other than two sentences, which I propose to read into the record.
—Order! The Minister is answering the question. As I understand it , he does not wish to make the statement in the full form of a ministerial statement. In that respect I will allow him to proceed.

—There is no foundation whatever for any suggestion that any Australian intelligence agency was engaged in any activity whatever in Chile at or around the time of the coup against President Allende. To the extent that some intelligence co-operation activity may have occurred at an earlier time, there is no foundation for any suggestion that Australia in any way assisted any other country in any alleged operations or activity directed against the Allende Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I refer to the discussions at the seminar on the draft defamation Bill which was held in Sydney on Saturday by the Media Law Association and the views of the seminar which were summarised by Mr McHugh, the President of the Media Law Association, who stated:

QUESTION.PARA: There is hardly a line in the Bill which has not been criticised and which cannot be justifiably criticised.

I ask the Attorney: Firstly, will he redraft the Bill in the light of the professional comment made at the seminar, as well as raising, as he undertook to do, various policy issues at the next meeting of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General? Secondly, will he invite the Standing Committee to consider the view of Mr Justice Hunt that it would be preferable not to attempt to codify the defamation law but rather to seek to achieve uniform modification of the common law?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly, as I indicated at the seminar, I remain fully receptive to suggestions not only about the policy content of this draft legislation which is, as Senator Durack will well know, the product of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General in an evolutionary exercise over the last four years to which he was a far more substantial contributor than I was. I have indicated my willingness to look, not just at the policy issues in relation to that legislation, but also at particular matters of drafting which may arise in relation to it. I indicated to both Mr McHugh and the former Attorney-General , Mr Hughes, who were present at the seminar and who also had all sorts of things to say publicly about the Bill, that I was willing to meet with them or with any group of senior practitioners in this area that might be put together under the auspices of the Media Law Association or perhaps the Law Council to look at the particular question of the practical operation of the legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: The policy matters which, at least before the seminar, I was disposed to raise with the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General will be raised at the meeting to be held in Melbourne on 16 December. It may be that, when I get a full report of what happened in the rest of the seminar when I was not there, there will be some other matters as well as those which I publicly announced which I will raise with the Attorneys.

As to the final question, namely, whether it may not be appropriate to engage in some modification of the common law rather than a complete codification, I simply say that the proposed uniform model legislation is not a complete codification-it does not purport to be-of the present law of defamation. It leaves plenty of room for operation of the rules of tort law generally and some aspects of defamation law in particular. I believe, as a result, that this aspect has been somewhat overstated by Mr Justice Hunt, although his comments and criticisms have been very helpful indeed in other respects and will certainly be taken very much into account as this rather difficult exercise continues and, I hope, is drawn to some sort of satisfactory conclusion next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Resources and Energy. On 14 September last, replying to a question concerning Wind Energy Tasmania Incorporated, the Minister for Resources and Energy stated that he had authorised the Department of Resources and Energy to seek discussions with the Hydro-Electric Commission on the collection of technical data on wind velocities and possible future co-operation, probably 12 months hence, in a technical study for wind-generated electricity in northern Tasmania. —I have no knowledge of what discussions have taken place with the Hydro-Electric Commission or any other bodies relating to data for wind power research. I will direct that question to the Department of Resources and Energy and obtain an early answer.

Further, is it true that a Department of Health paper advocates an increase in the health care levy to 4 per cent? Is this not evidence that Medicare is already in a bureaucratic and financial mess?

—As to the first part of the question about the number of forms allegedly under-ordered, I have no idea whether that is true but I will certainly find that out for the honourable senator. —Senator Primmer's question deserves a detailed reply. I will draw it to the attention of the Minister for Defence and ensure that he gets one.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Prime Minister . Further to Australia last year issuing a letter of intent to participate in the Louisiana Exhibition in the United States of America from 12 May to 11 November 1984, can the Minister advise how it is intended to utilise this most valuable opportunity to promote Australia, its people and its products? QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Leader of the Government in the Senate seen the front page of the Melbourne Age where it is headed 'The Good News-On Four Fronts'? Does the Minister have any comment on the present state of the Australian economy under the Hawke Australian Labor Party Government?

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a lot of interjections about what is now dignified with the description 'the EPAC study'. There was no such study. A forecast was prepared in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet in September for the Economic Planning Advisory Council. Even the authors of that so-called forecast in September expressed the view at the time that it was a very conservative estimate of the likely state of the economy and, in their own words , that they could have been much more sanguine than they were.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, everything which has happened since has justified the view of the authors of that report that they could have been more sanguine. For example, since that document was written there has been a totally revised estimate of farm production. Surveys have suggested a vast improvement in consumer confidence and--

TALK.START.PARA: —Lower capital investment.

—No, not lower capital investment. That is incorrect. The only forecast has been one of low capital investment, not lower capital investment. I shall come to that in a minute. That was a problem throughout the 1970s, when private capital investment was at a level, on average, of about one per cent of fixed assets.

ANSWER.PARA: But Senator Cook specifically directed my attention to the front page of the Melbourne Age. That records a very strong improvement of the manufacturing sector, with 21 out of 27 seasonally adjusted items showing increases as compared with the previous month, which was a month which showed increases as compared with the month before that. Production of raw steel was up by 9 per cent; production of cement was up by 10 per cent; production of bricks was up by 4 per cent; production of refrigerators was up by 15.8 per cent; and there were other substantial increases in the white goods area. Those increases in manufacturing production reflect a number of things. They reflect the rise and potential rise in farm income. They reflect the Government's stimulus to the housing industry. They reflect the general improvement in confidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —The wage pause.
—Any advance on the wage pause?
—There is nothing but retreat from the wage pause.

—I do not retreat from that. Of course the wage pause would have had some influence on these events. But the increases in production reflected in those figures show particularly the impact of the Government's policies in a number of areas. The figures for private capital investment are also heartening. They show that, after adjustment for inflation and seasonal factors, business expects to invest about the same in the December quarter as it did in the September quarter of 1983. The figures suggest that private capital investment is likely to be much better than was forecast in the Budget. The figures on average weekly earnings for all employees showed an increase of 5.5 per cent in the year to September, which in part reflects, as Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle pointed out, the wage pause. The share market is in a buoyant mood. The rural recovery is predicted to have a significant impact on the economy very soon and there will be substantial sums of money flowing to farmers by early next year.

ANSWER.PARA: All of these figures, as I and other Ministers in this chamber have said on a number of occasions, should be treated with the necessary caution. But they are in marked contrast to the gloom and doom predicted by some members of the Opposition-buoyant with gloom, as I said the other day, in the prospect that these figures are incorrect. What we have is a batch of good economic news indicating that the Government's economic policies are on track. I should also mention Melbourne University's Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research survey which recently found the biggest recovery in consumer optimism in the survey's 10-year history. That in itself is a very significant finding. As I said, the Government welcomes the figures. We welcome the front page of the Melbourne Age and particularly the rising fortunes of the steel industry, as reflected in the headline of the Melbourne Age, which are very important. I commend to all senators a close study of these figures, because it is very important that they be aware of what is happening in the economy, while treating the figures with caution, as I suggest, because this country has many problems ahead of it, although I think that we are justified in being satisfied with the current level of economic performance.

TALK.START.PARA: — by leave-I wish to report to the Senate that the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare is currently advertising its inquiry into Australia's retirement income systems in the national Press and is calling for written submissions from interested individuals and organisations to assist in the conduct of the inquiry. The closing date for submissions is 31 January 1984. Honourable senators will recall that on 6 September 1983 the Senate referred the matter of Australia's retirement income systems to the Committee for inquiry and report on, or before, the first sitting day in August 1984. In particular, the Committee is required to report on any changes which may be necessary to ensure equitable and comprehensive income security for Australians of retirement age.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has formulated detailed terms of reference to clarify the main objectives of the inquiry and to assist those preparing written submissions. These terms of reference also indicate those issues which the Committee believes warrant examination, without excluding other issues which may be brought to its attention in the course of the inquiry. The terms of reference for the inquiry are as follows:
1. The present and future financial needs and expectations of people of retirement age taking account of demographic trends, and changing social and economic conditions;
2. The adequacy of existing income systems such as age pensions and occupational superannuation schemes; and
3. Options for the future, with particular reference to-
(a) proposals for the modification of existing income systems,

(b) taxation and social welfare policies which provide for the equitable financing and distribution of social security benefits to people of retirement age (e.g. the appropriateness of income-testing, assets-testing and taxation of capital gains),
(c) the financial and economic implications of alternative national income systems for persons of retirement age, including a national superannuation scheme, and
(d) the need for subsidised services for aged persons (e.g. health, housing and transportation), and access to such services.

The Committee will also be considering the recommendations and proposals of earlier reports which addressed various matters within the scope of this inquiry , for example, the reports of the Asprey Taxation Review Committee, the Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty, the Hancock National Superannuation Committee of Inquiry and the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System as they relate to the provision of income security for Australians of retirement age. As part of the inquiry, the Committee intends to consider the retirement income needs of all people, including part time workers, the non-employed, the disabled, early retirees and women. It will also take account of such factors as changing work patterns and changing labour force participation rates and their effect on various retirement income systems.

I believe the inquiry is not only timely, in view of recent Government decisions affecting age pensions and occupational superannuation schemes, but also of vital importance to the present and future development of policy affecting the provision of equitable and comprehensive income security for people of retirement age. I further believe that it is appropriate for a committee of the Parliament, particularly a Senate committee, to be conducting an inquiry of this nature as such a committee will bring a bipartisan approach towards the inquiry. The recent increase in the membership of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare from six to eight senators also means that all major political parties in the Senate are now represented on the Committee. The Committee will be holding a series of public hearings in Canberra and interstate early next year. These meetings will provide a forum for individuals and organisations to express their views on issues raised in the inquiry's terms of reference.
