The speech read as follows-
This Bill is designed to implement the Australian Labor Party's platform as it relates to postal services.
The ALP Platform contains commitments to:
the development of an efficient postal system on the basis of a publicly owned national utility with exclusive rights to carry letters for reward;
the postal system to be available to Australians who reasonably require the services;
electronic mail to be handled by Australia Post; and
Australia Post to be empowered to competitively market a variety of services including high speed and door to door pick up and delivery services.

The Bill gives effect to these commitments by restoring the courier service, giving Post power to operate electronic mail services, by retaining and clarifying the monopoly provisions and allowing Post to enter a wider range of agency arrangements. The Bill gives effect to Government decisions following consideration of the Report of the Committee of Inquiry into the Monopoly Position of the Australian Postal Commission, the Bradley Committee, which were announced on 9 August 1983.

The major provisions in the Bill are those which give powers to the Australian Postal Commission to operate courier services and to establish electronic mail services in its own right. Honourable senators may recall that until 1980, Australia Post was successfully managing courier services in competition with the private sector; but under the short-sighted policy of the former Government its power to operate courier services was removed. This action was taken following the Review of Commonwealth Functions in the apparent belief that operation of courier services was a function which should only be undertaken by the private sector. The previous Government's decision was short sighted in that it did not take account of Australia Post's need to provide the full range of postal and related services including the kind of fast, personalised postal service which the community demands for items needing reliable special delivery treatment.

The power for Australia Post to operate electronic mail services in its own right is necessary to ensure the Commission can remain at the forefront of providing modern day communications services utilising the latest technological development. In general, electronic mail services provide for the transmission of documents by both electronic and physical means. The simplest example is the transmission of documents by facsimile, combined with physical pick up or delivery of the hard copy by the courier service. Other types of service are under study by Australia Post such as a bulk mail service using linked computers and mail preparation and delivery facilities.

It is difficult to forecast how electronic mail services will develop in the future or the degree to which thay may replace traditional services, but it is clear that Australia Post must be able to participate. There is a number of consequential amendments in the Bill which flow from the provision of power to establish courier and electronic mail services.

The Bill also provides for Australia Post to enter into agency arrangements with private sector principals. This is an extension of the existing power which enables Australia Post to enter agency arrangements with public sector principals. This measure will enable Australia Post to utilise its national network of post offices to provide supplementary services which should particularly benefit people in country areas. It also appears inequitable that private sector principals should be precluded from access to this network which is available to their public sector competitors. Extension of agency services in this way should lead to increased revenue to Australia Post thus benefitting all postal users.

Turning to the monopoly provisions for Australia Post, it needs to be borne in mind that these apply only in relation to carriage of letters. A good deal of Post's business such as the parcel post and carriage of non-letter articles is subject to competition. That competition comes from transport firms, courier services and the growing private delivery services. The Bradley Committee reaffirmed the necessity for Post's basic monopoly on letters to continue if Australia was to have a uniform nationwide postal service. The Government strongly endorsed that view as being consistent with the ALP platform. The Government considered a number of the exemptions to the monopoly proposed by Bradley. It decided to accept the recommendation that letters subject to a premium fee not be subject to the monopoly. Mostly such premium fees are charged by private courier services for speed pick up and delivery of letters. The amendment in the Bill will regularise this situation without putting Post's essential basic monopoly in jeopardy.

The Government has decided that the minimum premium fee should be ten times the basic domestic letter rate, currently 30c. This will mean, for example, that private courier services will be able to carry letters for reward exempt from the Commission's monopoly if they charge a minimum of $3.00. Similar provision has been made for private sector carriage of letters to overseas destinations.

The Bill also proposes a number of amendments of a technical nature such as allowing meetings to be held and decisions taken without all Commissioners being physically present. It extends the power to lease or sell any land vested in the Commission and increases the amount payable for rewards for information.

A further amendment allows for officers of the Commission to retire at the age of 55 years rather than at 60 years. This gives effect to another election undertaking of the Government and is complementary to a provision in another Bill before the Parliament which provides for a similar condition for officers of Telecom Australia.

The opportunity has also been taken to clarify and restate the powers of the Australian Postal and Telecommunications Commission to make by-laws. This has become desirable because some doubts have been raised about the effect of the procedures of notification adopted by the Commissions to this time. Because of significance of the by-laws to Telecom and Australia Post it has been decided to adopt the prudent approach of putting the validity of by-laws beyond doubt.

I believe the proposals in the Bill before the Senate will mark a significant milestone in Australia Post's operations. The powers encompassed in the Bill will enable Australia Post to offer new and dynamic services, make more efficient use of its extensive network of post offices, better meet the needs of the public and tap potential new technological developments which are both challenging and exciting.
Altogether, Australia Post will be placed in the position of providing fast reliable and comprehensive postal servives for the benefit of all Australians.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to provide legislative authority for a system that may be used uniformly throughout Australia for the service by post of summonses in respect of taxation offences that, on summary conviction, are punishable by a fine. The Australian Taxation Office issues more than 100,000 summonses annually throughout Australia for non-indictable offences against the various taxation laws. Most of these relate to failure to lodge income tax returns or to provide requested information. In some states-notably Victoria, South Australia and Queensland-taxations summonses are already served by post under relevant state laws. However, in Western Australia, Tasmania and New South Wales they are served personally by police officers, taxation officers or private process servers. Of the large number of taxation summonses issued in Australia each year a significant proportion is issued in New South Wales. Until now, service in that State has, by arrangement, been undertaken by the State police.

The New South Wales Government and the police association in that State have, for some time, been expressing the opinion that the use of police resources on this work is a waste of valuable manpower which, if released from this function, could be better deployed on law enforcement activities. With this general proposition the Government is in agreement, but we have been concerned to ensure that any system implemented to replace personal service should incorporate adequate safeguards.

Mr President, the proposed system contains essential safeguards to protect people from the consequences of non-receipt or late receipt of a summons or notice of conviction sent by post. A person convicted in his or her absence of an offence in respect of which a summons has been postally served and without entering a plea to the charge will be advised, by a notice which may be served by post, of details of the conviction, of any fine imposed and of the time allowed by the court for payment of the fine. This notice will also advise the convicted person of rights available under the system to apply for the conviction to be set aside and the charge reheard. Where the court hearing an application for setting aside a conviction is satisfied that the postally served summons was not received either at all or in sufficient time to enable attendance at the hearing of the charge, or where the court considers it desirable in the interests of justice to do so, the conviction is to be set aside and the matter reheard.

The system will also provide that, if any fine is not paid within the longer of the time allowed by the court or 21 days, a warning notice must be personally served on a convicted person and a further period of 21 days allowed to elapse before he or she can be imprisoned for non-payment. Following personal service of this warning notice, there will be a further opportunity to seek a setting aside of the conviction and to obtain a rehearing of the charge. The court would , however, need to be satisfied that the summons and notice of conviction were not received or were not received in sufficient time to enable the person to appear at the original hearing or to have earlier exercised the right to have the conviction set aside and the matter reheard. In the event of non-receipt or late receipt of a summons there will therefore be at least two opportunities to have a conviction set aside and to obtain a re-hearing before a warrant of commitment to prison may be issued.

The system will in general provide safeguards greater than those contained in the laws of States and territories which now provide for the service of summonses by post. In no case will the proposed Commonwealth system provide fewer safeguards. The system will be implemented initially in States in which personal service of summonses is at present carried out, namely, New South Wales , Western Australia and Tasmania. I also mention that in States and territories where persons may, under State or Tterritory law, enter a plea by post to a charge of having committed an offence, that procedure will also apply in relation to summonses for taxation offences served by post under the new Commonwealth system.

Mr President, the introduction of the system provided for by this Bill will not result in any cost to the revenue. There will, however, be savings for State police forces in the States in which police officers now personally serve taxation summonses. Some savings in Commonwealth expenditure and resources will also result in States in which summonses are now served by taxation officers or process servers. A memorandum explaining the technical features of the Bill is, as is usual with taxation bills, being made available to honourable senators. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The description of the Bill and the need for national legislation are already in the Hansard and do not need to be repeated. The major amendments incorporated in the Bill were described by Senator Evans on 20 October 1983. One thing is clear. Despite the changes made, the fundamental principle of the Bill remains unchanged; that discrimination based on sex, marital status and pregnancy and discrimination involving sexual harassment cannot be tolerated in our society; and that in public life-work, education, accommodation, the provision of goods, facilities and services, the disposal of land, and the administration of Commonwealth laws and programs-any such discrimination should be unlawful and there should be a means of redressing discrimination where it occurs. As I have said, this fundamental principle which is widely endorsed throughout the community is not changed at all.

I will now describe briefly the final changes that have been made to the Bill. These fall into two categories, alterations dealing with exemptions and alterations dealing with procedural matters. One of the most controversial amendments already announced has been the provision relating to educational institutions established for religious purposes. It has been argued that non- government schools should be free to discriminate on the grounds of sex, marital status and pregnancy in respect of the employment of staff and the admission and teaching of students: That would mean that such schools would be free to act quite without regard to the basic principles of equality on which the Bill is based. The Government does not accept that this should be so.

The major fear appeared to be that a school which taught its students that marriage was sacred, might be forced to employ teachers whose lives were a denial of this view, because they lived in a de facto relationship-and that schools may even be forced to accept teachers living in de facto relationships with students at the school. I should point out that any teacher who engaged in sexual activity with a student, whether it was a de facto relationship or not, would be disciplined and that this would not constitute discrimination on the ground of marital status.

As honourable senators know the Government treated the concerns of these schools seriously and first considered a two year partial exemption to enable the Human Rights Commission to report on the nature of the exemption that should be granted.

As this did not meet the concerns of some spokespersons for non-government schools a further exemption was announced on 20 October 1983. It was also criticised because religious schools do not regard themselves as established to provide education in accordance with the doctrines of a religion or creed and asserted that the doctrines of the religion would not require dismissal of teachers in de facto relationships.

With these comments in mind we have in this Bill included a revised exemption- at clause 38-which covers discrimination on the ground of sex, marital status or pregnancy in the hiring and firing of staff at schools conducted in accordance with the doctrines, tenets, beliefs or teachings of a particular religion or creed where the discrimination is done in good faith in order to avoid injury to the religious susceptibilities of adherents of that religion or creed.

Sub-clause 38 (3) contains a similar exemption dealing with discrimination on the grounds of marital status and pregnancy in relation to the educational practices of such schools. The revised provision should allow schools to act in accordance with the religious teachings on the basis of which their schools are conducted, while still endorsing the basic principles of equality. I should point out that schools cannot treat teachers or staff differently on the basis of their sex, marital status or pregnancy while they are employed, or deny educational benefits to students on the basis of their sex.

There are also alterations in clause 37 dealing with religious bodies to extend it to the selection and appointment of acolytes, deacons and so on and in the language of the final paragraph which has been broadened.

As honourable senators will know the Government had announced an amendment to what is now clause 22 to make clear what was already implicit in the Bill-that it did not apply to the provision of services the nature of which is such that they can be provided only to people of one sex. I should comment here that the Bill is concerned only with discrimination between people because of their sex, marital status or pregnancy in services that are provided, and not with forcing people to provide particular services. Similarly the Bill does not force employers to take on more staff-only that when staff are employed they should be selected on merit and without discrimination.

To avoid the real concern that people feel about the effects of what is now clause 22 the Government, as I have said, announced the amendment to clarify the situation. We have now moved the amending provision to clause 32 and it provides that nothing in Divisions 1 and 2-all the provisions dealing with discrimination on the grounds of sex, marital status and pregnancy-applies to services the nature of which is such that they can only be provided to people of one sex. I hope this put the matter beyond doubt. Defence force employment of women is now covered in clause 43 and the provision has been altered slightly to allow more flexibility in the drafting of regulations. These will now cover combat duties, combat related duties and can include circumstances relating to those duties.

Clause 106 deals with the vicarious liability of employers and principals. The Bill had already provided for employer and principal liability where the employee or agent does an act that would be discrimination on the ground of sex, marital status or pregnancy if done by the employer or principal. The new provision makes it clear that this is so whether or not it would be unlawful for the employee or agent to do the act. Clause 106 also covers employer and principal liability for acts of employees and agents that constitute sexual harassment-these must be acts in connection with employment or duties as an agent. The practice of sexual harassment can be eliminated only when employers take positive steps to eliminate it from the workplace and make clear to their staff that it cannot be tolerated. Clause 106 makes it clear that an employer or principal who has taken reasonable steps to prevent employees and agents from engaging in any form of discrimination will not be liable.

The other amendments to the Bill are procedural. Clause 65, dealing with legal representation, now enables parties to have legal representation without the leave of the Commission where the Commission has made arrangements for counsel to assist it. This change has been made because such inquiries can be expected to be very formal. In other cases representation will be by leave of the Commission. Clause 60 is a new provision to enable the Commission to have a quorum of three for an inquiry-the Chairman or another legally qualified member will preside.

Sub-clause 82 enables a complainant or the Commission to bring an action in the Federal Court to enforce a determination of the Commission. Sub-clause (2) of corresponding clause 74 in the original Bill provided that where the Commission had stated findings of fact, those findings were prima facie evidence of the matters contained in those findings. It was never intended that this should force a respondent to prove that those findings were wrong-only that the complainant should not have to prove a case for the third time in circumstances where the facts were not in dispute. We believe that there would be nothing to prevent the parties from agreeing on statements of facts in the absence of this provision, and for this reason it is not repeated in clause 82.

The provisions in the Bill relating to self-incrimination are now contained in clause 91. This differs from clause 82 in the original Bill in that the privilege against self-incrimination is only removed in proceedings before the Commissioner and not before the Commission-the prohibition on using information obtained or documents produced before the Commissioner, in evidence in a court, remains.

Under clause 90 of the Bill, refusing to answer a question or produce a document to the Commission is an offence unless the person has a reasonable excuse. Sub-clause 91 (2) makes it clear that refusal on the ground that to do so might incriminate the person is a reasonable excuse. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Martin) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I congratulate the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) on the Government's decision, finally, to have the Bill reprinted and for her acknowledgment of the need to rethink such an important Bill. I also congratulate her for her acknowledgment of the slipshod drafting of the Bill. There have been 53 amendments to the Bill before we have actually got round to finishing the debate on it. I hope that the Government will also acknowledge the input from the Opposition on many of the amendments that the Government has accepted. As I said, I am pleased to see this Bill finally reprinted so that it will be possible for us to deal with it in the Senate in a sensible fashion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Casino Control Ordinance 1983 contained in the Australian Capital Territory Ordinance No. 53 of 1983 and made under the Seat of Government ( Administration) Act 1910 be disallowed.

There are two aspects to this matter and I wish to deal with each of them. The first, in particular, relates to the rejection by the Government of a proposal to develop a hotel and convention centre and office complex. In place it wishes to put up a building which incorporates a casino. Some questions need to be answered about the casino. Why do we need a casino? Who wants it? Who benefits from the Government's decision to place a casino in Canberra? On 18 October 1983 the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) put out a Press statement which sounded, at the beginning at least, as though the Government was confirming a decision which had been made previously in favour of the complex. This statement read:
. . . Mr Tom Uren, today announced Government go-ahead for a complex involving an international convention centre, hotel and office accommodation in the ACT.

As I said, that sounds like a reaffirmation of the project which had been approved previously. For six days prior to that statement there had been gossip in Canberra that there was to be a casino. In fact, the casino was referred to in the next paragraph of the Minister's statement which read:
Mr Uren said the complex would also incorporate a casino. 'Negotiations for this proposal-
that is the previous one-
have now been called-off although I have invited White Industries to tender for the new proposal.'

The Minister referred in his statement to employment opportunities but made no mention of employment opportunities additional to the ones previously available under the White Industries Ltd proposition. Presumably, the additional employment prospects come from the casino itself. I shall refer to them in due course. He referred also to urgently needed office space. Of course, that could have been just about built by now if the Government had gone ahead with the project in March of this year and had not fooled around with the idea for so long. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Gietzelt, who is in the chamber, knows how badly Canberra needs office accommodation. His Department had difficulty in finding a quite small area of accommodation for an office of the Department of Veterans' Affairs in Canberra, as he admitted in the Senate only recently. There has been a delay of nine months already.

The Department of Administrative Services referred to this matter quite recently. The site was to be developed by White Industries Ltd. It was to be held in one ownership and no charge was to be made for the land. There was to be a 99-year lease and rates were to be abated for five years. The Commonwealth wanted to lease the office space available, subject to reasonable terms-of course, the Commonwealth knew that it needed the space-the Government was to give an undertaking to make maximum use of the convention centre and the National Capital Development Commission was to give all possible assistance. Those terms made it appropriate and possible for a hotel-convention centre to be built in Canberra, which is something we need. It has been stated on many occasions that the development of tourism and projects associated with the development of tourism are necessary in Canberra. The Canberra Association for Regional Development has said it; the Canberra Development Board has said it; and the Government has said it, but they do not do much about it.

Perhaps the real tragedy of the decision is the disincentive to private investment which has been caused by the treatment of White Industries. It is quite contrary to the expectations that the people of the Australian Capital Territory had of this Government from the rhetoric which they had heard previously. The honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) was reported in the Canberra Times of 18 February 1983 as follows:

. . . the ALP was committed to a convention centre for Canberra, without the requirement for a casino. It supported the White Industries proposal which provides for a five-star hotel and convention centre.

That statement was reported on 18 February 1983. Of course, it was not until after the election that the rumours about the abandonment of that proposal started to float about this community. Everybody knew that it was local Australian Labor Party policy to oppose a casino. What other expectations did we quite reasonably have? The House of Assembly in the Australian Capital Territory was to be consulted about any significant decisions. The Canberra Times of 20 February 1983, under a headline 'Labor launches its ACT campaign', referred to the then shadow Minister for the Australian Capital Territory in this way:
He said after the campaign launch that a Labor government would 'introduce directives that the Assembly has to be consulted on all ordinances affecting Canberra'.

This casino ordinance affects Canberra. Up until the time of this ordinance, which is No. 53 of 1983, there had been, obviously, 52 ordinances. Two of those were referred to the House of Assembly after gazettal. Which two were they? They were the Casino Control Ordinance and the Canberra Commercial Development Authority (Amendment) Ordinance, in relation to which I have also moved for disallowance. It is pretty obvious what consultation really means. There is consultation if it suits. If the Government thinks there will be any opposition from the community there is no consultation; the ordinance is brought into effect and it is then left for us in the Senate to move for disallowance.

Who wants this casino? Who will benefit from it? Apparently, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that the people of Canberra will benefit from it. If that is the case, why does he not give the details of the benefit? Why will he not consult with the people? On 7 September 1983 the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) made a statement regarding financial impact statements. I concede that he related them to second reading speeches and not to ordinances, but I would say to the Government: Why not relate them to ordinances? Mr Dawkins said:

In future all second reading speeches of Ministers will include a statement of a financial impact of the legislation. These statements will include estimates of any significant costs, revenue and savings arising directly from that legislation where such estimates can be calculated readily and reliably.

If the Prime Minister is so certain that this casino will be of great financial benefit to Canberra why did he not provide us with a financial impact statement giving details of the costs, revenue and savings arising from this legislation, including the cost of the compensation that may need to be paid to White Industries as a result of the way in which the company has been treated? In the same statement the Minister for Finance said:
Ministers will also attempt to assess the impact on industry and other sections of the community when formulating legislation.

Obviously the Australian Capital Territory is not important enough for the Government to bother assessing the impact on this community of a casino or the community's views about whether it wants it. I wonder whether these words are as hollow as far as other legislation is concerned, or whether it is only the Australian Capital Territory which gets treated in this manner.

I return to the questions I have already asked, to which we have no answers: Why do we need a casino, who will benefit from it and why was it necessary to bring in this legislation with what has been referred to as indecent haste? The legislation comprises some 30 pages with 10 pages of explanatory notes. After seven months of fiddling around with the White Industries proposal, the legislation was announced, as I have said, on 18 October 1983; consented to by the Governor-General on 28 October 1983; gazetted on 31 October 1983 and tabled in the Senate on 1 November 1983. The speed of events was absolutely breathtaking. It is worth pausing just for a moment to consider the speed with which some other legislation is dealt within the Australian Capital Territory. I refer to taxi fare increases. In March a proposition was put up to the Minister for an overdue increase in taxi fares and other allowances. On 25 August the Minister issued a statement saying that the new fares, which he had agreed to, would come into effect when necessary amendments were made to the Motor Traffic Ordinance. One would have thought that that would have been a matter of high priority if one had any regard whatever for that sector of the business community. But no, the new schedule of the actual increase in fares was introduced on 24 October 1983. In round figures it took two months.

What about legislation as a result of the inquiry of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation into hazardous chemicals, air and water pollution, dangerous goods, the disposal of pesticides and veterinary chemicals? One would think that all of those issues were very important to this community. The initial report of the Committee was made on 29 April 1982. The second report was made in December 1982. There is still no Government response to most of the matters raised in those reports and no legislation either. On 26 May 1983 the Minister for Territories and Local Government informed me in a letter in relation to amending legislation about the operation of multicabs in Canberra:
I have asked that the necessary amendments be given a high priority.

What is the date now? We still do not have the legislation. So much for high priority of things that are important to this community. We are still awaiting legislation regarding noise control. So the list goes on. I could go through other areas, but there are more important matters to talk about. What has been the community response to the proposal that the White Industries development be abandoned and that the casino be developed? It has been suggested that there be a referendum. That suggestion has been rejected by the Prime Minister, out of hand it would seem, although the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) seems to think that it would be possible to hold one. Who knows. The Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford) has been involved in this matter also. He talked about the creation of jobs. We know that the number of jobs, other than those involved in the casino, is roughly the same for this project as the previous Government's project, the project which should be proceeding right now. From the beginning of the arrangement there is very little difference in the number of jobs involved. The Minister referred to those who oppose the casino as 'academic wowsers'. That expression is contained in his Press statement of 19 October 1983. I suggest to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that that is a totally inappropriate way for a Minister to express himself about people who have a different view on something from that which he holds. It is a pretty poor state of affairs in this country when people with an opposing view on a matter such as this are called academic wowsers by the Minister for Housing and Construction.
The only reference which we have regarding extra jobs is that provided by the Prime Minister in answer to a question in the House of Representatives on 16 November 1983. He said:

No section of the Australian people is suffering more from unemployment than young women. It is without question and beyond the possibility of argument that if a casino were established in the Australian Capital Territory it would provide, in its construction, employment for a considerable number of people-
that is certainly true-
and, in its operation, large levels of employment for people and particularly for young women who otherwise would not be able to get employment.
He did not elaborate on what he meant but in view of some of the reports and royal commissions on organised crime and vice one is terrified to think about what he might have had in mind.
Let us go back to the people to whom the Minister for Housing and Construction referred as academic wowsers. On 22 October, the Canberra Times reported:
ACT Labour Council opposes casino.
The article continued:
The ACT branch council of the Australian Labor Party has endorsed its opposition to Canberra's proposed casino.
'We decided after extensive debate that we still opposed the building of a casino in Canberra', . . .

Mr Fred Daly is well known in this Parliament, well known in this community and is well respected. He now lives in Canberra. He has criticised the Government's decision to force self-government and a casino on Canberra without obtaining the people's opinion. In a letter to the editor of the Canberra Times, he wrote:
. . . eventually, most governments get around to deciding that they know what is best for the people'.
'The Hawke Government, however, on a crest of a wave, have reached this point more rapidly-a little over seven months', . . .
His letter continues:
. . . 'Then the casino-another we-know-what's-good-for-you decision.
'It's not a question of whether you gamble or not, but whether this type of social activity to be established in the national capital. Personally, I do not think it is.

His letter continues with more of the same. Other people in the community have commented on the proposal. I have received many letters and many letters have been published in the Canberra Times. Concern has been expressed about the impact a casino would have on the clubs in Canberra.

A decision was made by the House of Assembly, as I said. The ordinance was not referred to it before it was made law, but it has examined it since. By a very convincing majority of 10 votes to 8 the House of Assembly rejected it. Of the ten only five were Liberals, so one can hardly say that it was a vote along party lines. It is very interesting to note that, of the six Australian Labor Party members who voted against the Assembly motion, six do not support a casino . A Press statement was put out by the leader of the Labor Party in the House of Assembly dated 22 November 1983 in which she complained about the way the media reported the Assembly decision and the ALP's position with regard to it. On page 2 of that statement she said:
The ALP-view not to support any proposal for the construction of a Casino-was established on Sunday-
which was 20 November-
and at no subsequent stage was this position changed. The ALP did not vote for a casino.
It certainly voted against a motion which related to this topic and the White Industries proposal together, but she was very clear when she said:
The A.L.P. did not vote for a casino.
In reality, the vote of the House of Assembly on a casino is 16 to 2. If the Government is not prepared to take notice of that, I cannot think how it can stand up and talk about self-government.
There is another letter to which I wish to refer. In relation to the setting up of a gambling casino in Canberra, the author says:

I believe this is a matter best decided by the majority of people living in the area, and that the views of the community should be ascertained before steps are taken to incorporate such a controversial establishment in the local scene.

That was signed by Bob Hawke, President, Australian Council of Trade Unions and was dated 31 May 1977. We are entitled to ask him why he has changed his mind. He has not told us why he has changed his mind.

The effect of this decision would be a major disincentive to the private development of Canberra. White Industries and the $130m which was to be used for the construction of the project have been left up in the air for seven months. It would be an irresponsible decision if it had been made in March; it is highly irresponsible made at this time. I cannot think who would argue with the proposition that we need to diversify our economy; we need to expand the range of job opportunities; and we need to encourage private investors to come to Canberra with projects that encourage tourism, with industry and with business. The real debate, I guess, is about jobs. What has happened? The project has been abandoned. It is consistent, of course, with the Government's attitude to the private sector.

Tourism, as I said, is important. It is apparent from the Federal Budget in one part that the Government regards it as important, but not here. An amount of $ 500,000 was granted for the promotion of tourism in 1983, the same figure exactly as was granted in 1982 without any increased amount to cover the cost of inflation. There has been an average increase of 68 per cent in grants by State governments for tourism promotion this year. The amount granted to the Canberra Visitor and Convention Bureau on a dollar for dollar basis was the same as that granted for 1982, that is, $30,000. In fact, it spent considerably more than the $30,000; it spent $50,000. The Canberra Development Board has been downgraded. No new executive director has yet been appointed. If the ordinance is not disallowed, a new shopping complex is to be built by a statutory authority competing with the private sector. The Government has rejected the proposal for land servicing being done by the private sector except for one small proposal which the Minister said is a one-off deal. The attitude of this Government to the private sector, in spite of what the Minister for Territories and Local Government said at the National Economic Summit Conference shows that the Government does not care about it.
Who wants the casino? Mr Alan Ramsey in the National Times on 31 October, in a quite long article, made it pretty plain. He said:

The real initiator of the casino proposal is the Prime Minister. Hawke raised it with Uren personally after Cabinet in May had considered the so-called Tivoli Gardens project which the Fraser Government approved just a few weeks before it lost office.

There is very good reason to think that that is probably true when one reads the letter that the Prime Minister wrote to the Speaker of the House of Assembly on 14 November 1983. In the two-page letter he spoke about the substantial benefits which will accrue to the citizens of Canberra, but he does not spell them out, and the employment opportunities-we know about them-short term and long term. He referred to the acute shortage of office accommodation. If he had gone ahead with the project in March that should have been proceeded with and that I ask him still to proceed with, he would be well on the way to having office accommodation by now.

In a letter which he wrote to Senator Chipp on the matter, he said that he had 'informed the Assembly'. That expression in itself is noteworthy. He referred to the benefits but again did not spell them out. Interestingly enough he said that governments are elected to govern. I say to him: Get on with it and stop building shopping centres and interfering in that area as well. He said:
There would in any event be a difficulty in following the course . . . suggested-
as far as the referendum is concerned-
. . . to be held on 25 February next.

Although the Attorney-General, on television, did not seem to have the same worries about the prospects of a referndum on the matter. Other references indicate that the Prime Minister is very committed to this project. Perhaps worst of all is the threat to this community that if the Senate does not support the casino Canberra will get nothing; he will pick up his bat and ball and go home. Mr Barry Reid, the Deputy Leader of the ALP in the House of Assembly, prior to the Assembly considering the report-it is reported in the Canberra Times of 18 November-said:
Plans for a hotel-convention centre and office buildings in Civic would be abandoned if the ACT House of Assembly failed to support the Government's proposal for a Canberra casino . . .

Government source confirmed yesterday that if the casino proposal was not endorsed by the Assembly . . . and passed by the Senate . . . it was most probable that the entire project would be abandoned.

Why is that? How could any government be so vindictive as to say: 'You will have a casino or you will get nothing'? That proposition was also confirmed by the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) in a television interview. That in itself needs to be thought about.

Let us go through what we are really talking about. The Government will not hold a referendum and will not consult with the people of Canberra. It brings in subordinate legislation in the form of an ordinance which cannot be amended; not a Commonwealth statute, which one would think would be appropriate for a matter like this and which could be amended. There is a part of the Ordinance which ought to be amended but which we do not have the opportunity to amend. It was not referred to the House of Assembly in spite of a commitment to do so. It has caused great delay in going ahead with the project which was to have been ready for the World Athletics Cup in 1985, which would have provided jobs during this year and which would provide office accommodation. The Government has a total disregard for the needs of this community and the people in the Boulevard area who are very interested indeed in seeing this development go ahead.

There have been many reports which this Parliament has heard about and which have dealt with other aspects of why a casino is not regarded by many people as a desirable asset in the community. Reports of royal commissions have been discussed. They have referred to organised crime. They have referred to the involvement of gambling interests in casinos. If in fact this is not correct, is the Government able to assure us that there is no connection between organised crime and casinos? Can the Minister set people's minds at rest on this issue and explain to us why it is that so many people feel that there is a risk of organised crime being involved with a casino? The authorities in the United States of America and Britain have not been able to curb criminal involvement in casino operations and they, of course, have had a great deal more experience in this area. There was discussion about this matter at the Congress of the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science held in Perth only this year. Mr Douglas Meagher, in one of his papers, said:
One of the oldest businesses of organised crime in Australia has been the conduct of casino type operations.

He referred to the extensive report of Mr Justice Moffit in the early 1970s. He referred to casino type operations often being combined with vice operations. The most recent report that bears study is that of Mr Xavier Connor who reported for the Victorian Government earlier this year after an 11-month inquiry. Mr Connor is a respected member of this community. The Prime Minister could have asked him to look at the position in regard to the Australian Capital Territory. What did Mr Connor decide for Victoria? He said of casinos:
They would be likely to stimulate casino gambling to an unacceptable degree;
there is no substantial demonstrable demand for them.
That was in Victoria. The only person who has been very vocal in demanding a casino in Canberra seems to be the Prime Minister. Mr Connor said:
there would be a substantial risk that in one way or another they would be infiltrated by organised crime elements;
they are likely to be accompanied by an unacceptable level of street crime;
they are not, by comparison with certain other forms of gambling, likely to be efficient procedures of revenue for the State of Victoria.

Nothing has been produced to us to show that a casino in Canberra would be likely to be an efficient producer of revenue for the Australian Capital Territory. A casino is being inflicted upon us. The White Industries proposal is being abandoned because of it. The private sector is being treated harshly and unjustifiably. I say to the Government that it should go ahead immediately with the White Industries hotel, convention centre and office complex.

The question still lingers: Who needs the casino; who wants the casino? Why does this community need a casino? There really are a number of uncertainties and unanswered questions which this community is entitled to have answered by the Government. Great harm has been done to the development of Canberra by the delay in going ahead with the project and by the way the developer has been treated by being asked to hang around for some eight months. We need the jobs; the project should proceed forthwith. The $130m involved is available. If it does not go ahead, I wonder how much compensation will have to be paid to White Industries. Has that matter really been thought about?

Of course, the other outstanding question that I hope the Minister will answer is: Who is to get the casino licence? That is something we are entitled to know. Who is being brought into this community with that casino licence? I hope the Minister can assure us that, if the Senate rejects this Ordinance, the Government will go ahead with the project that we all know about and understand, and that it will go ahead with it immediately; that the threat and the blackmail to this community about this matter are not typical of the real behaviour of this Government. Of course, if it is, the rest of the country ought to be told more about the way the Government behaves to a small community involving not only Federal Government but State and local government. Others should know the sorts of standover tactics that are used when dealing with a small community. I urge the Senate to support the motion to disallow the Ordinance.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Chairman of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I am not entering into the policy question of the casino, but I wish to report briefly that the Regulations and Ordinances Committee examined the Casino Control Ordinance and decided not to give notice to disallow the Ordinance as, from the Committee's point of view, there are no provisions which offend the established principles of the Committee and which would justify disallowance. I also add that the Committee, on one minor point, agreed to write to the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) seeking his views on the desirability of qualifying one particular provision in section 49 (4) under which an inspector can be authorised by warrant to use force in search, entry and seizure operations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion for disallowance of the Casino Control Ordinance which has been raised by my colleague Senator Margaret Reid. This original Ordinance would enable the construction of a casino in the Australian Capital Territory. That I have to speak on this matter through a motion for the disallowance of an ordinance is an incredible indictment of a Prime Minister who came to power trumpeting that his Government would be a government of consultation and consensus. Electors were not given to expect that important decisions would be taken secretly in an attempt to bypass the forums of Parliament. Of course, we in Tasmania have learned to look very carefully at regulations, following our experience with the particular issue of the South West Tasmanian dams. I understand that the Australian Labor Party platform stated that it would investigate the feasibility of establishing a casino in the Australian Capital Territory. We have had no investigation, certainly not to the public's knowledge, but just a blunt announcement that the Tivoli Gardens concept was frozen and that there would be a casino accompanying a convention centre. The Canberra Branch of the ALP was not consulted. The House of Assembly was not consulted, nor were the people of Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: Yet the Government cannot really hide behind the defence that it was surprised by the local, and possibly national, opposition to this scheme. Three times in the last six years a casino has been suggested. Each time, following opposition, the proposal has been dropped. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) have failed to give a single reason why the development should now go ahead. It is incredible how the Federal Government is prepared to give with such speed a go-ahead to a project which will cost at least $150m and which will change the character of the national capital. The Government announcement hoped that tenders could even be called before Christmas. This is in direct contrast to the cautious way in which ALP governments in South Australia, Victoria and Western Australia have acted. Victoria set up an inquiry headed by Mr Xavier Connor, QC, which sat for 101 days of public inquiry. The South Australian Government legislated for a casino but selected a site and a licensee which were subject to the most vigorous public scrutiny by a three-man authority which was headed by a judge. Western Australia initiated a public inquiry into the whole question of casinos.

Just what justification has been given for the urgency of this proposal? I suggest that it is merely two hackneyed 'apple-pie' phrases-employment and tourist potential. No evidence has been offered to show the extent of these benefits, as my colleague Senator Reid has just outlined. By cancelling approval of the White Industries Tivoli convention centre and offices, the Government has delayed employment in the construction industry. Discussion of a new casino cannot ignore the findings of Mr Xavier Connor following his thorough inquiry in Victoria last year. His report, the report of the Board of Inquiry into Casinos, found that casinos should not be established in Victoria for the following reasons:
They would be likely to stimulate casino gambling to an unacceptable degree;
there is no substantial demonstrable demand for them;
there would be a substantial risk that in one way or another they would be infiltrated by organised crime elements;
they are likely to be accompanied by an unacceptable level of street crime;
they are not, by comparison with other forms of gambling, likely to be efficient producers of revenue for the State of Victoria.
Mr Connor concluded:
I consider that the above considerations outweigh any likely benefits such as increased economic activity, increased State revenue and social enjoyment.

I am not aware of any important factors which would make Mr Connor's findings irrelevant within the Australian Capital Territory. In fact, its geographical location within New South Wales and the presence of the Federal Government could make the findings even more pertinent to the Australian Capital Territory.
On 24 May this year the Victorian Premier, John Cain, an Australian Labor Party man, announced his Government's decision not to proceed with a casino. He said:
This Government is not prepared to expose this State and its citizens to the avoidable risk of introducing a facility upon which organised crime could prosper.
Mr Cain went on:

We do not propose to test the capacity of the police force or any regulatory body which the Government might establish to supervise casinos and therefore we have come firmly to the view that no casino of whatever variety should be set up in this State.

What are the perceived benefits of a casino for the Australian Capital Territory ? There is great difficulty in predicting the effect of a casino on employment as such. Certainly there would be benefits during the construction stage, and I think that everyone would recognise that; but after that, it is largely unknown. The gambling dollar is not infinitely stretchable, as Tasmania is now discovering. As Mr Connor pointed out:

It must also be conceded that there could be some significant rearrangement of the gambling dollar and perhaps a more significant drop in TAB revenue. Current employment levels arising from other forms of gambling could be reduced.

Tasmanian horse racing illustrates this effect. Increased government sponsorship has been necessary for the continued prosperity of the industry. In that State the industry is currently being reconstructed.

From a revenue point of view, a casino is not necessarily a gold-mine. Mr Connor recommended that, if revenue were the principal consideration, lotteries and the racing industry were better bets-using gambling terminology. The Government has held out revenue to be used for the social benefit of the people of Canberra as the carrot for this project. If that is so, the local people should ensure that they get the very best carrot that is available. Mr Connor said:
They are not, by comparison with certain other forms of gambling, likely to be efficient producers of revenue for the State of Victoria.
I believe that the same criterion, the same reasoning, would apply in the Australian Capital Territory.

Many contradictory figures are trotted out to prove that a casino enhances tourism. Certainly Tasmanian tourism increased with the opening of the Hobart casino. But the evidence now points to a resumption of the normal tourist curve. It must also be remembered that there is a vast difference between the tourism potential of Australia's first casino, which was established in Hobart, and a future one in Canberra competing with four existing casinos and with proposed casinos in Queensland and South Australia. It is also the dream of a supreme optimist that a casino-convention centre will attract a vast horde of international conferences to Australia, and to Canberra in particular. Improved facilities for national conferences would be advantageous, but many international conferences would be deterred from coming to Australia, not by lack of a casino but because of distance, travelling times and high fares, particularly when other countries offer far more incentives than Australia offers.
The point of most concern to me is the potential crime risk attendant with a casino, the risk both of organised crime and of street crime. Again, Mr Connor said:
There would be a substantial risk that in one way or another they-
that is, casinos-
would be infiltrated by organised crime elements . . . Casinos are likely to be accompanied by an unacceptable level of street crime.

There has been sufficient publicity this year of alleged organised crime in New South Wales, of reports of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and of the Special Prosecutor Mr Redlich to alert Australia to the reality of organised crime which is already taking place in Australia. Therefore, there seems little sense in increasing the risk and, in particular, in bringing organised crime into closer proximity with the law makers and the public servants. As John Cain pointed out, casinos are an avoidable risk which is not necessary. The people of Canberra are entitled to feel cheated and badly treated by the Hawke Government, even those who relish the idea of a casino. They were not consulted about this latest casino project; they were presented with almost a fait accompli. They are the ones who will have to live with the increased risk, not we the politicians who only come and go in the Territory. I support the motion of my colleague Senator Reid for the disallowance of the Ordinance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats believe that it is impertinent for a group of politicians, such as Senator Watson from Tasmania, such as me, from Victoria, and such as certain other people, to make a decision for the people of Canberra, without consulting them, and say: 'You will have a casino' or 'You will not have a casino'. The Democrats very strongly believe that such a significant decision as this ought to be made by the people of the Australian Capital Territory. They ought to be given an opportunity of registering their idea of the impact that such a significant decision would have on their way of life. As Senator Watson says, we who come from other States and other cities are in this city of Canberra for about 90 or 100 days and nights a year; that is all. The rest of the residents have to live here all the year, and they would have to suffer or enjoy the benefits that a casino might bring to them.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a significant decision. The Government has said that from the profits of the casino money will be made available for social welfare, and that it will not be money that subtitutes for present hypothecations of revenue to social welfare . It will be a topping up of what is already there. That is very commendable. One would commend the Government for that sort of high purpose, but I ask: Has any sort of economic viability study been done to ensure that there will be profits of this magnitude that will materially assist social welfare in Canberra ? I am told, and Senator Watson and the Tasmanian senators would know better than I, that the casino division of the Wrest Point Federal casino and the Launceston Federal casino are now not as lucrative as they used to be. In fact, I have heard some suggestions that the profits in some cases have turned into losses. I am also told that the profits of the casino part of the Alice Springs Federal Hotel are not as were expected.

Do we have any economic viability statement for the proposal in the Australian Capital Territory? Has any survey been done on the effect or the impact of a casino on the clubs in Canberra? What will it do to them? As Senator Watson said , the discretionary dollar that is spent on gambling in most cases, except in the case of compulsive gamblers, is not elastic. I think that was the term he used. There is only a certain amount in discretionary dollars that can be earmarked for gambling. What impact would the casino have on the social and ethnic clubs of Canberra which, in my judgment and experience, perform a very valuable social function in this city? What effect would it have on the racing clubs of Canberra and Queanbeyan? I do know that the casinos have had a catastrophic effect on the horse racing clubs of Hobart and Launceston. What impact would a casino have on the charities that are run and organised in the Australian Capital Territory?

Then comes perhaps the most serious problem of all: What would it do to organised crime? I have never been too concerned about the effects of organised crime on casinos located well away from high density populations. But good heavens, in the Australian Capital Territory we are only three or four hours drive from the most densely populated place in Australia, Sydney, and within striking distance of Melbourne. One needs only to read the report of Xavier Connor, QC, to have some chilling fears about a casino erected and run in such close proximity to large centres of population.

Arguments have been put to me that it is inappropriate for a capital city to have a casino. I must confess that I am not quite grasped with the strength of that argument, but it has been put to me and I must say that of the hundreds of letters I have received about a casino, almost every one has been against it. That does not necessarily test public opinion but it certainly gives an indication of its flavour. The Australian Democrats' view is that if ever there was a classic case for reference to the people to register a view, it would be on the question of whether the Australian Capital Territory should have a casino . There are no great scientific equations for ordinary people to contemplate or to understand. It is not a complicated debate in the sense that the debate on the fluoridation of water could become complicated. It is a simple and straight forward question: 'Do you believe that the benefits a casino might bring to the Australian Capital Territory would outweigh the possible detriment?' I believe that we Federal politicians who do not live here owe the people of the Australian Capital Territory the chance to say what they want.

One might well say that the members of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly, the democratically elected representatives of the people, have already made a decision. When one looks at the vote closely, that issue becomes a little clouded. What was voted on on 21 November was the following matter: In a debate lasting two hours the leader of the Liberal Party in the House of Assembly, Mr Jim Leedman, put a motion outrightly opposing a casino. It was quite stark. It just said: 'notes Message No. 115 and rejects the proposal that a casino should be built in the A.C.T.'-it has some addendum but that was the thrust of it-to which there was a quite complicated amendment moved by the Leader of the Australian Labor Party, Maureen Horder. In effect, it favoured the casino but said: 'Let us wait and make further evaluation'. There was a tied vote on the Horder amendment, nine-all. I would hardly say that that was a thunderously decisive vote of the democratically elected people of the House of Assembly. The amendment was negatived because the vote was nine-all. Then the Leedman proposal, that the Assembly was against the casino, was carried on the slightest of margins, 10 to eight. Now those in favour of the Horder amendment were eight Labor Party members and one Democrat.

TALK.START.PARA: —A 1-1-1-landslide, as a famous parliamentarian would have stuttered.

—Yes, I wish the stutter could be put into Hansard. It would lift my speech considerably. Against the Horder amendment were five Liberal members, two Family Team members, one Independent and one Australian Democrat. The Leedman motion was carried by a vote of 10 to eight. Those in favour of the motion were five Liberals, two Family Team members, one Democrat and two Labor Party members. Against it were six Labor Party members, one Independent and one Democrat. I do not know whether that is a representative view of what the people of the Australian Capital Territory believe, whether ten-eighteenths of the population of Canberra do not want a casino. I do not know because sometimes the members of major parties vote as the party machine dictates. The Labor vote was more complicated than usual because as I understand it local Labor Party policy in the Australian Capital Territory is against a casino whereas the Federal Labor Party wants a casino impacted on the people of Canberra. It must have really put the Labor members of the House of Assembly in some sort of dilemma.

SPEECH.PARA: With the greatest of respect to the members of the House of Assembly I am not going to take this as a truly representative vote of the people of Canberra. If this Ordinance, which is now law and which will remain law until either repealed or disallowed by this chamber, is disallowed by this chamber-namely if Senator Reid's motion is carried-it will be another six months before the Government can introduce a similar ordinance. Although I have a personal view about whether Canberra should have a casino, which I believe can be judged by the contents of my speech, I do not want to deny the people of Canberra a casino if the majority of them want it. Clearly if the project is going to get off the ground in the soonest possible time, simply to throw out this Ordinance this afternoon would inevitably set back any contemplation of a casino for at least another six months. I do not want that.

I wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) suggesting that a referendum might be held on the matter and that to save costs it might be held on the same day as the referendum of 25 February. I have no worries about quoting from the Prime Minister's letter to me because he seems to have the quaint idea that if you write to him your letter is from you to him only but his reply is put in the Press boxes. That is what his staff did with his reply to me. He said:

With respect to your suggestion that there should be a referendum on the subject, my firm and long held view is that Governments are elected to govern and to make the decisions which need to be made. To resort to referendums, unless required by the Constitution or on a matter of the greatest national importance, would rightly be seen as abdication by a Government of its responsibilities. I do not see the casino issue as one which could possibly justify such a drastic step.
I marvel at the idea that to go to the people to ask their opinion on something is such a drastic step. The Prime Minister goes on:

If the Commonwealth-or, for that matter, the House of Assembly-makes a decision in this matter that is widely considered to be wrong, the electors will have their chance to pass judgment at the appropriate time.

One wonders from where the Prime Minister believes that he or his Party got a mandate to introduce this measure. One wonders whether, if a casino is established in Canberra it could, as the Prime Minister suggests, be removed by a subsequent government. I very much doubt that once such a thing is established in a society it can be removed. The Prime Minister properly suggested that there were some difficulties under the Commonwealth Electoral Act which includes a provision that on a day when a national election or referendum is held a State election or referendum will not be held. I do not know whether that applies to the Territory. Even if it did, I cannot see any difficulty in having even an unofficial referendum on the day of the Federal referendum on 25 February which would, at least, give the people of Canberra an opportunity to cast a straw vote on whether they needed a referendum. It would be a far better indicator than that which we now have.

I have asked the Government to reconsider the question of a referendum. As I understand it, it is prepared to reconsider the question without any undertakings being given. Therefore, I believe it would be in the interests of the people of the Australian Capital Territory if this debate today was adjourned until next Tuesday. There would still be plenty of time to disallow the ordinance if it be our wish. I give notice now that the Australian Democrats would vote with the Opposition to disallow this ordinance next Tuesday unless the Government agrees to a referendum. As I understand it, the machinery for doing so could be as follows: At its Cabinet meeting on Monday, the Government could agree to a referendum; if it is supported by Caucus the Government could repeal this ordinance, have the referendum, and then reintroduce another ordinance or some other arrangement, as it sees fit. With that in mind, and after paying the Government and the Opposition the courtesy of suggesting this course of action and, as I understand it, having received agreement from both sides that this is an appropriate course of action, I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gietzelt for Senator Ryan)-by leave-proposed:
That Government Business, Order of the Day No. 3 (Sex Discrimination Bill 1983) be discharged from the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In giving leave for the Sex Discrimination Bill to be discharged from the Notice Paper, I suppose I have indicated that the Opposition will not object to this motion. Indeed, we welcome the removal of the Bill from the Notice Paper. But I wish to say a couple of things about the matter. On 9 November 1983 I addressed a question to Senator Ryan about the Sex Discrimination Bill. In the course of that question, I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . does she agree that it would speed up consideration of the Bill if it were withdrawn and redrafted, incorporating the many amendments which the Government has now found it must make to make the Bill a reasonable piece of legislation, in the Government's view?

I received what I can only regard as a rather churlish and abusive response from Senator Ryan. She suggested, for example, that I had accused the Government of ineptness and incompetence for continuing with the legislation in a form which would require a number of amendments. I think that any reading of my question would make it quite clear that I was not accusing the Government of ineptness and incompetence. Senator Ryan was setting up a straw man to knock down. The honourable senator also accused me of insincerity in my comments in wishing to facilitate the passage of the Bill. She went on to say:

We have considered the possibility of withdrawing the Bill and redrafting it to incorporate the amendments but after lengthy discussion with Parliamentary Counsel officers and other relevant experts we decided it would not facilitate debate and discussion. Honourable senators will wish to discuss particular amendments, and are entitled to do so. I believe the form in which the Bill has been presented, with the amendments incorporated into the text, clearly set out in different type faces and so on-
There was then an interjection from Senator Tate, which destroyed Senator Ryan's flow of language, but she went on to say:
It is a clear presentation of the Government's intentions and a useful indication of the amendments we have made as a result of the consultation process.

I also asked as a supplementary question at that time whether the Minister expected to introduce any further amendments. She said that whilst it was not set in concrete, she did not expect there to be any substantive amendments. In fact, the suggestion that the Bill be withdrawn and represented in a whole form incorporating the many Government amendments was first made privately to the Government in a meeting which I, along with the Honourable Ian Macphee, who is the shadow Minister responsible for these areas, had with the Minister. I raise the matter again because I believe that the Minister showed very great discourtesy in responding to what I had to say. She made a number of accusations and statements which now clearly are no longer representative of the view of the Government. I think that the prospect of dealing with what would now be probably some 60 or more amendments to that Bill would not be one that would lead to a good consideration of that legislation in the Committee stage. I believe that the Government has decided to follow a more sensible course. I regret that when the matter was raised both privately and in this chamber the Minister saw fit to respond in the way that she did.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 November 1983, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Upon which Senator Lewis had moved by way of amendment:

Leave out all words after 'That', insert 'the Bill be not further proceeded with until the Government has provided a Financial Impact Statement in accordance with the undertaking given by the Minister for Finance in a Ministerial Statement made to the House of Representatives on 7 September 1983, and tabled in the Senate on 8 September 1983'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As requested, I make a statement-on the basis of the information available to the Government at this time-on the financial implications of the Representation Bill 1983. As the Government has already said in presenting this Bill to Parliament, an increase in the size of Parliament is not only long overdue but is something which must eventually come about. We have said that the time is appropriate to make these changes now-now that we are updating and consolidating our electoral legislation and now that we are preparing to move into the new Parliament House.

SPEECH.PARA: There is, in fact, a point to be made about the new Parliament House. It has been designed in such a way that the needs of the next 200 years can be met, albeit at some additional cost. Even though the proposed increase of 12 senators and 23 members will entail additional costs-which have not yet been finally calculated-I am sure that all senators will appreciate that to proceed with alterations at this stage would be far less costly, and certainly more conveniently arranged, than if the inevitable decision to increase the size of the Parliament were made in, say 10 years time, five years after the building has been completed. Estimated ongoing costs per annum for an additional 12 senators and 23 members are as follows:

$m 1. Salaries and electorate allowances 1.93 2. Travel (fares, allowances, transport) 1.45 3. Office costs, including accommodation and equipment, postage and telephones, but excluding Joint House Department costs, which have not been able to be estimated in the time available 1.08 4. Staff salaries, allowances and travel 1.72
The estimated annual cost to the proposed Australian Electoral Commission of maintaining an additional 23 divisional offices is $3.17m. The total estimated annual cost is therefore $9.35m.

Alternatives advanced by the Opposition are not free nor are they cost effective; we have considered all the alternatives and we believe our proposals are the most democratic and efficient. It has been suggested that an alternative to an increase in the size of Parliament is to provide each senator and member with an additional staff member. The estimated annual cost of this alternative is $6.2m, but this expenditure would not provide the same representation benefits to electors as would the slightly higher investment envisaged by this Bill.

In addition some senators have suggested that members of Parliament and senators require vastly improved facilities, such as computers, word processors, vocadexes and new telephone systems; these items are of course extremely costly to provide and preliminary estimates from the Department of the Special Minister of State show that the provision of even a modest package of word processor, vocadex, telex and commander telephone system, would be in the proximity of $4m.

The Opposition has continually advanced the proposition that the nexus between the House of Representatives and the Senate should be broken before any increase in the size of the Lower House is contemplated. But even if such a referendum were to be carried-which will be very difficult in view of the likely opposition from the smaller States-this would not really result in any significant cost reductions. The proposed increase in the size of the Senate would reduce the estimates outlined above-that is, the figure of $6.18m-by less than one-third and of course would not influence the $3.17m figure which is for the 23 divisional offices that are required.

The further difficulty that the 'nexus' referendum proposal faces is that-as I said at more length in my reply to the debate on the Constitution Bills in the Senate on 13 October-the running of this question as a sixth question next February 25 will impossibly complicate the task of securing the passage of the other proposals. It may be appropriate for this proposal to go forward at some future time-at a referendum which, incidentally, if held by itself would cost some $20m-but that time is not now.

The Government believes that the cost of increasing the size of Parliament as proposed in the Representation Bill presently before the Senate is a small price to pay for an improvement in the quality of our democracy-for more adequate and realistic representation for all Australians and for a more effective Parliament .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement in response to the statement made by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans).
—You are already in continuation, Senator Lewis.
—Yes, I have about seven minutes left.
—That is ample for you; you are pretty good.
—I recognise that I am much better than the honourable senator but I need more than seven minutes to have a go at this statement.
—Order! Senator Lewis, do you still seek leave to make a statement?
—Yes.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President.
—My statement was to shorten the debate, not lengthen it.

—I will be just a few minutes. I draw attention to the need for the Government to carry out its undertaking to provide us with information such as that contained in the Attorney's statement at the time of second reading speeches because the whole purpose of providing such information is to give the Parliament the opportunity to consider the cost to the country of the Government 's proposals. The Minister for Finance, Mr Dawkins, made great play about what his Government was doing in adopting the proposal for financial impact statements. Now, as the Representation Bill is about to come on for debate, we are provided with information which, on the face of it, is clearly dicky-let us say rubbery, to use a term which is well known.
—What do you mean 'dicky'?

—It certainly is. There is proposed here an estimated annual cost of $9.35m to provide all of these additional senators and members and their staffs and then further down we see that it is estimated to cost almost $6.2m just to provide staff. The Attorney-General cannot tell me that those figures are not rubbery in some way. All I want to say at this stage is how terribly wrong it is for the Government, having grand-standed about intending to provide the Parliament with information that would enable us properly to debate these matters, to provide us with this sort of crappy information just a few minutes before the debate is to continue.
—Order! Senator Lewis, although you have made a statement you are still at the top of the speakers' list, in continuation, for the Representation Bill.
—I am aware of that.
—You may continue.
—I take it, then, Madam Acting Deputy President, that other senators do not wish to debate this statement?
— Put it this way, Senator: No other honourable senators leapt to their feet with any enthusiasm. So I call Senator Lewis.

—It now appears as though the reason for my motion before the Senate has been overcome. While the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, was going through his statement I tried to assess the provisions contained in it. I draw attention to the fact that apparently the Joint House Department costs have been excluded from the statement. The estimated annual cost of the operation of the Representation Bill is $9.35m; but, if we add the costs of the Joint House Department, we are talking about $10m per annum.
—There is no superannuation in this, either.

—Senator Withers has found another matter in the few minutes that this statement has been before us. No superannuation is included.
