The point is that I estimate that it was worth at least $5m per annum, and I might tell the Senate that when I made that estimate Senator Robert Ray, from Victoria, laughed and pooh-poohed it. However, I believe the estimate is near enough to $10m, on the Government's own figures, if we take into account the Joint House Department . That is the annual cost. What I seek to know, what I asked last Friday week when we were debating this matter, is what other costs are involved. Does the Government intend to expand this building in order to cope with the 36 additional members of Parliament.
—No, we don't.
—The Attorney-General says no. I do not know where people will be placed. Has the Government taken into account the cost of additional staff?
—Is the Attorney going to share his office?

—We will ask in the Committee stages with whom he is going to share his office. The other answer I want to know is what will be the cost of that new parliament building up on the hill, because 36 additional suites will be built into that building and in addition it may very well be that dining rooms, for example, will have to be expanded.
—No, nonsense.

—The Attorney-General interjects and says that no, there will be no need to expand the dining room. That would surprise me; but of course he knows more about the building than we do, having had something to do with it in the initial stages. It may very well be that he can tell us, when at some stage he responds, what he thinks the capital cost of the additional extensions will be to the nation.
—Perhaps they can take it off the age pensioners.

—Yes, as Senator Withers says, perhaps the Government could take it off the age pensioners or someone. In any event, I think the Parliament is entitled to know what will be the whole cost of this project. We do not want just the estimated annual cost. We knew that it would be an insignificant sum- the Government apparently thinks it is insignificant-of $10m per annum. We want to know what it really will cost.
—Democracy is involved; cheap at twice the price.

—I am interested to hear that the Attorney-General thinks that democracy would be cheap at twice the price. He thinks it would be worth while having $20m per annum spent on additional parliamentarians and that somehow or other an addition of 36 parliamentarians would bring about democracy in this nation. That is a lot of rot because this Government is not interested in democracy. We seek this information. I shall certainly be asking questions during the Committee stage. I alert the Attorney-General now that I will be seeking information on the estimated cost of other things which are floating around and which are not included in the financial impact statement which the Government has now brought down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Almost all of the arguments for and against the Representation Bill 1983 have been elaborated upon at length by honourable senators who have taken part in this debate and consequently I do not intend to speak for more than a couple of minutes. I believe that one is either for or against a Bill of this type. One is either set in one's views on the arguments for or against such legislation. I can understand some of the arguments that have been advanced for the Bill. I can understand some of the pressures that may be building up in the States which, as a result of a habitation review and the resultant electoral redistribution, are likely to lose one or two seats in the House of Representatives. We should bear in mind that although the purpose of this Bill is to increase the size of this chamber, in reality the Bill will enable an increase to take place in the size of the House of Representatives. We all know that this would happen because of the constitutional nexus between the numbers in the House of Representatives and the numbers in the Senate. If it came to a decision between breaking the nexus or voting for this proposition, I would vote for this proposition.
—Why?

—I make that perfectly clear. Senator Georges has asked why. All of the arguments that have been advanced against that proposition have in fact been put to the people by referendum and the people in no uncertain terms voted against the breaking of the nexus. I put it to the Senate this way: Whilst I can understand some of the arguments, I do not agree with them. I particularly do not agree with those arguments that have suggested that the volume of work has developed to such a stage that more members of the House of Representatives and more senators are required. Our affairs can be ordered in such a way as to ensure that parliamentarians can cope with the volume of work. Except in some committee areas, there is no way known that the volume of work will decline as a result of an increase in the number of members of Parliament. I acknowledge that exception.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been suggested that a considerable volume of work has been generated in electoral offices since 1949 when the last major increase in the membership of the Parliament took place. That is true. However, a number of other factors have had an influence since 1949. I refer to the work of the Ombudsman, various administrative appeals provisions and better departmental facilities in regional areas in terms of social security, housing, immigration and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Communications.

—Senator Archer mentions communications. I recognise that for more than one reason it must be a drag for Senator Withers to have to travel from Western Australia to Canberra. However, let us take ourselves back to 1949. I do not know how long it took to travel from Western Australia to Canberra in those days.
—Two days, by air.
—Yes, it would have been about two days. I can get from Hobart to Canberra in a matter of three hours or thereabouts, perhaps 3 1/2 hours.
—You obviously don't travel by TAA.

—I do, frequently, because Trans Australia Airlines has a direct flight to Melbourne on Tuesdays. Leaving that aside, look at the advances that have taken place in technology. The advance in information retrieval technology is just one example. All of the Commonwealth legislation is on the SCALE system, the Statutes and Cases-Automated Legal Enquiry system, in the Parliamentary Library. One can walk into the Library off King's Hall, punch a few words into the computer and get the answer in ten seconds flat. The other day I wanted to find out whether the words 'de facto spouse' that are used in the sex discrimination legislation are contained in any other Act of the Commonwealth Parliament. The people in the Library simply punched the words in and seven seconds later out came the reply, no. Imagine how long it would have taken in 1949 for that piece of information to have been obtained.
—Five seconds, because they didn't have such nonsense.

—That gets to the point. I think Senator Withers has hit the nail on the head. Will an increase in the number of parliamentarians mean that there will be any more wisdom around this place? I do not think it will. I do not want to canvass all the arguments that have been advanced. However, bearing in mind both sides of the argument, on balance I believe that this Bill should not be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak briefly. As a Tasmanian I want to make my remarks in the context of how this legislation affects the Tasmanian situation. I start by asking: However could any Tasmanian support this Bill? Are parliamentarians the best judges of what is best for their electorates ? I do not think that that is necessarily the case. Far too often we are inclined to look at things in terms of whether they will be comfortable to us rather than what will be best for the people we are supposed to represent. Do we take enough notice of what the electorate thinks is best and how many members it thinks we should have in the Parliament? Are parliamentarians too involved with their own comfort and convenience? Are we trying to avoid the real point of the legislation, which of course is simply a matter of how the Government goes about increasing its numbers? The primary cost, as has been suggested by the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) will be about $9.35m, or $10m in round figures. It amazes me that the Government intends to spend $10m in this way. Of that amount, $5m has been misappropriated by the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) from the schools-
—I raise a point of order. Senator Archer cannot use a word such as 'misappropriated'. I ask for that word to be withdrawn.
—I withdraw that term. The amount of $5m that would have gone to the schools has now been-
—Siphoned off for the pollies.

—It has been siphoned off and put into the fund to pay more politicians. I am sure that that will not be greatly appreciated. The other $5m could have paid for the Wynyard Airport development in Tasmania. Although that project was actually under way and an election undertaking had been given that it would continue, the money allocated was perhaps not misappropriated but redirected into the area covered by this legislation. This Government decided that this money would be better spent on having more members of parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know whether any of the other Tasmanian members of parliament are likely to go into various parts of the State and try to convince the people that the money that would have gone towards the development of Tasmania is better spent on having more members in the Federal Parliament. How could any Tasmanian support this legislation? The Tasmanian State Government has, very sensibly, been talking about a reduction in the number of parliamentarians. Two gallup polls have shown that 84 per cent and 87 per cent of people do not want any more members of parliament. We do not listen to those people because the fountain of all wisdom in this place says that we need more members of parliament. What a classic case of electoral expediency ahead of the clear views of the voters which have been totally expressed and clearly understood.

Any change made to the current situation will weaken Tasmania's position relative to the rest of the States. It is not so many years ago that Tasmania had five members out of 75 members in the House of Representatives. What the Government is proposing now would give Tasmania five members out of 150 members, which actually halves Tasmania's representation. That may be all very well for the centralists. Any of the centralists would welcome such a thought but I do not think that any of the Tasmanian people would welcome the fact that a centralist Government was trying to edge them out more and more. We have had evidence of how the centralist Government would like to edge out Tasmania. This is purely and simply just another example. Not one single Tasmanian representative or Tasmanian could justify there being 12 senators from Tasmania.

The Special Minister of State (Mr Beazley) in his second reading speech dealt at length with the expectations of the electorate. He said that the volume of work and the volume of legislation had increased, as if that were a reason for increasing the number of members. Although the Minister talked about the people' s expectations and what they wanted from their members of parliament, he did not go so far as to say what their expectations were about the number of parliamentarians they felt was required. I do not know why he so coyly omitted that point. Clearly what is required by the electorate is more work and better representation, not more members. We will achieve a lot more by having better members, not more members. Mr Beazley-incidentally he is the Minister who was overseeing the cancellation of the funding for the Wynyard Airport-is the man who decided to put up this legislation to have more members of parliament. In his second reading speech he said:
Today the Parliament through the ordinary back bencher is expected to be conversant with these new policy trends . . .
I cannot see that more members will make the ordinary back bencher any more conversant with these trends. He states further:
. . . with the flood of constituent problems . . .
The flood of constituent problems could be better dealt with by more staff in the electorate office than by a member of parliament here in Canberra. The Minister went on to say:
. . . the position of not being able to serve their constituents . . .

These sorts of phrases appear throughout the Minister's second reading speech. More members will do nothing towards alleviating the problems mentioned in the Minister's speech. I mention that point in the Senate because I believe it is very valid. All these objectives can be achieved by allowing members to service their electorates better. The Minister also mentioned the fact that the New Zealand Parliament has only 92 members and that each constituency averages only 22,117 electors. I resent the fact that the Minister has referred to the New Zealand situation because he did not go on to say that we should bear in mind the fact that New Zealand does not have State parliaments and has only one chamber in the national Parliament. The figure of 22,117 would be similar in many respects to the number of electors who are represented by each member of parliament in Australia. I think that to include that sort of reference without qualifying it in some way is being a little less than totally honest. The Minister-I like this point-went on to say:
It will permit the improving committee system to become more effective in improving the legislature's oversight of the Executive.

I do not think the Minister was here during the last sitting week when we were endeavouring to get a better oversight of the National Crime Authority Bill. If Mr Beazley is going to talk about having a better oversight he ought to clear it with Senator Gareth Evans before he goes on in the way he did about the National Crime Authority Bill. I gained the distinct impression during that week that Mr Beazley may find that the increased scrutiny of some of the Executive and its Bills might be a bit hard to sell. I come back to a factual note. There is absolutely no way at present that we can produce the resources to provide adequately for 35 extra memebers and senators. We all know that. There is not the physical capacity in this building and in the areas around it to do that at this stage.

I do not accept the statement put down by Senator Gareth Evans a few minutes ago which purported to be representative of the costs. The statement is a piece of paper that tries to prevent us from getting at the costs. Such figures could be produced by almost any of us in two or three minutes. The real costs are shielded. I believe that Senator Gareth Evans should send the figures back to where they came from and say: 'We asked for a complete set of figures and we still expect to get it'. The figures contained in the statement do not have anything to do with the real costs involved. It does not show any estimates which related to how we will suddenly produce all the extra offices required. It does not show how many extra staff will be needed for Hansard or the dining room . It does not give an estimate of how many additional attendants or drivers will be needed. It does not include the cost of extra cars that would be involved or the extra cost of furniture and typewriters. Capital costs such as these are not included. I think that the capital cost of providing these services for a member of parliament would be $100,000 or more. No reference was made to that in the statement. I would certainly like to know at what cost, why and how it will be done.

I feel we are a long way short of having heard any justification for this Bill. Speaking as a Tasmanian, I think it is significant that no Tasmanian has yet tried to support the Bill. Frankly, there is no way any Tasmanian could possibly support it. I hope that representatives of the other States, particularly the smaller ones, will see the Bill for what it is and help to see that it is soundly defeated.

TALK.START.PARA: — Before I commence my speech I make the point that I had originally put my name on the speakers' list to take part in the debate on the Representation Bill but when I was told on the last Friday on which the Senate sat that agreement had been reached between the Whips that debate on the Bill would be completed on that day I took my name off the list. We saw on that Friday, obviously at Senator Chaney's instigation, an increase in the number of speakers on the list every time it looked as though debate on the Bill would be completed on that day. The last speaker, Senator Lewis-we have just heard him complete his speech-made a disgraceful speech in which he was clearly filibustering until 4.15 p.m. I do not blame Senator Lewis personally. It was clear that he had been instructed to keep talking until the Senate adjourned. We all saw the notes that were passed to him and the geeing up that occurred so that that would happen.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Robert Ray put the Labor Party's position on this legislation quite thoroughly in an excellent speech but I wish to make a few extra points. Before I discuss the arguments raised against this Bill I will quickly run through the changes proposed and the reasons why they are considered so necessary by the Government and, incidentally, by the National Party. The Representation Bill proposes that the number of senators in each State increase from 10 to 12 and the number of House of Representative members increase from 125 to 148. The number of Federal parliamentarians has remained the same since 1949 whereas Australia's population has practically doubled in the same period. Presently, there is an average of 75,000 electors per electorate compared with about 40,000 per electorate in 1949. The new legislation will bring the figure to 65,000 electors per electorate, a figure which still does not compare favourably with the situation in the United Kingdom, where there are just over 40,000 electors per constituency, or in the Canadian lower House where the average number of electors per electorate is about 56,000.

I have heard some criticism of this Bill by people who say that the increase in the House of Representatives seats will be in the outer suburbs of the large cities of Sydney and Melbourne. That is just not true. New South Wales, for example, will get eight additional seats if this legislation is passed. I spent last weekend at the Cowper Federal electorate council on the north coast of New South Wales. In that area there are three seats which at present are all held by the National Party-Richmond, which is held by Mr Anthony, Cowper and Lyne. Those three seats between them at present have 67,000 voters over quota. So, if this legislation goes through and each seat has 65,000 voters, the National Party stronghold on the north coast of New South Wales will gain at least one new seat on the present figures with an additional 2,000 over quota. With the redistribution which is likely to occur in that area there is a certainty of one additional seat and perhaps two. There will certainly be an additional seat in the surrounds of the city of Newcastle and at least one additional seat on the central coast of New South Wales. So, in New South Wales, at least four of the seats will be in areas well away from the outer western suburbs of Sydney and the number may be as high as five.

As Senator Ray pointed out earlier in the debate, the various State parliaments have increased the number of their elected representatives since 1949. The increases range from 14 per cent in the Western Australian lower House to 25 per cent in Queensland and the lower House in Victoria. The proposed change in the Federal Parliament in this Bill represents a modest increase of 16 per cent. Members of the National Party, who are supporting this Bill are realists, even if their main concern is to increase their representation. They are legitimately entitled to do so, particularly as in recent years they have been squeezed out of Senate representation in a number of States by the Liberals. Victoria is a State that comes to mind. There always used to be a National Party senator from that State. From New South Wales there is only one National Party senator at the moment. The National Party in New South Wales has the same number of seats as the Liberal Party and on any reckoning the National Party should be entitled to an additional senator. It has only one out of five senators at the moment.

Most of the massive electorates are held equally between the Government and the National Party. With the redistribution due soon there is the possibility of an electorate such as Grey, which already covers 90 per cent of South Australia, being increased in size to about 92 per cent to 94 per cent of the State just to take in the necessary voters to bring it back to quota. I believe there is a need for more Federal parliamentarians. Since 1949 the areas of Federal Government responsibility have grown enormously and constituents' expectations and needs have risen accordingly. Consequently, it has become increasingly difficult for a senator or member to fulfil his or her obligations in the electorate as well as in the Parliament, particularly in the Senate, bearing in mind the increased demands of the Senate committee system.

I now wish to examine some of the opposition to the legislation that we have heard in this debate. The main argument against the legislation is the issue of cost. Honourable senators opposite argue that in these times of economic difficulties such a proposal is too expensive. I ask all honourable senators opposite: 'How can they put a price on democracy? Let me give one example. India is probably one of the poorest countries in the world but it is the world's largest democracy. It runs elections and a parliamentary democracy at horrendous costs compared with the average income of its citizens. Would any Opposition senator not support the idea of elections taking place in India or of having a parliamentary democracy in that country? I believe the cost of running the Parliament is not an argument at all. Of course, the cost of implementing this legislation will be significant but the benefits greatly outweigh the cost. The paper brought down by the Attorney-General, Senator Evans, this afternoon indicated that the proposal will cost $9.35m per annum. I will get back to that figure later. To many people it is never the right time to increase the size of the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —You ask the people in the electorate; they will tell you.

—It is interesting to hear the interjection from Senator Archer. Some Tasmanian senators who opposed this Bill on the grounds of cost also opposed the Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill-the referendum proposal which, if accepted, would mean that House of Representatives and Senate elections would be held simultaneously. A half Senate election costs the Australian taxpayer between $17m and $20m which makes nonsense of the argument about cost. When the simultaneous elections referendum proposal was brought up in the Senate quite recently, Senator Archer, Senator Townley and Senator Walters all voted against it. I do not know where Senator Watson was. Yet those honourable senators now argue about the cost of increased representation. By voting against the simultaneous elections proposal, they voted for the retention of half Senate elections which cost an additional $17m to $20m every time they are held. There is as much weight in the argument on the cost of half Senate elections as there is in pointing out the nonsense of the argument about the cost of increasing the size of the Senate and the House of Representatives as put forward in this Bill.
—That is absolute rubbish and you know it.

—It is not absolute rubbish. If Senator Walters had been in the chamber she would have heard one of her colleagues from Tasmania talking at length about the Opposition opposing the proposal because it would cost $9.35m per annum. That is exactly the argument that he was using.

SPEECH.PARA: Another argument put forward by the Opposition and by Senator Lewis, which in my mind trivialises the issue, is the concern that there will not be enough accommodation to house the new parliamentarians either in the present Parliament House or in the new Parliament House. That is a ridiculous notion. Offices in the present Parliament House are being transformed, renovated, divided and enlarged constantly. A number of us quite recently got double offices. If necessary we would have to go back to occupying single offices. Surely the argument is nonsensical. Finding space should not be a problem. Certainly it can be overcome. Of course, the new Parliament House has made provision for an increase in the number of parliamentarians. It would be ludicrous to believe that the architects involved did not take into account the fact that an increase in senators and members was likely to occur in the not too distant future. If the architects had not taken account of that we should have sacked them.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the jury.

—As Senator Evans was a member of that jury, I will accept his point. He might recall that I am also a member of the Joint Committee on the New Parliament House. The architects took into account what they thought would be the needs of the Australian Parliament for the next 200 years. Even if they had not, they would have had to take them into account some time in the future. If there are alterations-I believe alterations could be required-it will certainly be a lot cheaper to do them now than at some time in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: Further claims were made in the debate that additional staff members and better facilities are required in preference to more members of parliament. It was argued that this would be cheaper and would also solve the present difficulties of coping with extra constituency and parliamentary work. Whilst I am sure that all honourable senators would welcome another staff member and updated facilities, it is not necessarily the answer to the issue at hand. I think that Senator Missen spoke of United States senators with staffs of up to 100 people. Gratefully, most honourable senators in the debate did not think this situation was very satisfactory. Constituents do not always want to see a staff member about their problems. They insist, and rightfully demand, to see their elected representatives. Their elected member is expected to be visible, available and active in the electorate. That role is becoming more and more difficult to achieve.

As Senator Evans said this afternoon, if there were an increase of one staff member per person we would be looking at a cost of $6.2m per annum. Most members of the House of Representatives, particularly those who represent the far flung areas of Australia, would say that they need an increase of at least two staff members per person. If that were agreed to by the Government, not looking at the cost of telexes, vocadex and other implements which I believe are extremely necessary--

TALK.START.PARA: —You know it is a grossly inflated cost.

—I am talking about an increase of two. Everybody will get a chance, at the Committee stage, to state how he works out his own figure. Whilst members of the Opposition attack the figures put down by the Minister for Finance, Mr Dawkins, in one way, they have to accept the figures in the other way. What I am saying is that if they use one figure in their argument they should look at the other figure which would show that an increase of two staff for every MP would amount to at least $12.4m a year. As I said, this does not include telexes and the other equipment that people who represent north Queensland and Western Australia require. Some honourable senators opposite have played up on the fact that public opinion is very heavily opposed to this legislation.
—Just give us the right figures.

—When did Senator Archer's Government ever provide any estimate of the legislation which it brought before us? It never did. As I said, some honourable senators opposite have played upon the fact that public opinion, they say, is heavily opposed to this legislation. I wonder how many people who have been interviewed or polled really understand the issues at stake or the facts about why these changes are so necessary and important. I wonder how many people who were polled have studied the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform before they recorded their opinion. I think the answer would be none. If a public opinion poll asks people whether they want more politicians, I think that everyone here knows what the answer will always be.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators opposite also expressed some concern about the possibility of the Senate being deadlocked because of the even number of senators-that is, six-to be elected in a half Senate election. Senator Missen was concerned that the Government would be in the hands of one or two individuals. He rested his opposition to the Bill on this point, even while he acknowledged the worth of increasing the number of MPs at this time. However, I believe this argument is groundless. The position is unlikely to change from the present position which is in effect a deadlocked Senate. Furthermore, the Senate has been deadlocked more often than not in recent times. Yet, on the other hand some of Senator Missen's colleagues argued that the new system would wipe out minority parties because if the two major parties receive 43 per cent of the vote the split would be three senators each. I think that we on the Government side are entitled to ask: What is the Opposition's position as far as this argument goes?

It was rather ironic to hear Senator Baume claim how tragic it would be if minority parties were no longer in the Senate. He stated that governments have been able to function well with minority parties in the past. I bet that is not what he thought this time last year when his Government was struggling to get through its legislative program before Christmas, in exactly the same way as we are struggling to get our legislation through this year. This argument is fallacious anyway, as another Liberal senator, Senator Teague, kindly pointed out for us. He stated that on 1980 and 1983 figures a minority candidate who was elected in the No. 5 vacancy situation would also have been elected in a No. 6 vacancy situation. Senator Macklin from the Australian Democrats was in opposition to the Bill. I think his main concern, which should be the concern of all the Democrats, was that in this legislation they would lose out. If one looks at the figures-

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I did not mention it in my speech.

—If I were a member of the Australian Democrats I would be wondering whether this legislation would wipe out the Democrats. I am sure that that was in Senator Macklin's mind when he looked at the Bill. Senator Teague pointed out-this is supported by Senator Robert Ray's figures which were incorporated in Hansard-that the person who was elected in the No.5 vacancy in both the 1980 and 1983 election would have been elected in a six-vacancy situation. As Senator Ray rightly stated last week when discussing this legislation the most likely result from a half-Senate election on the 1983 figures would be that the Government would get three senators, the Opposition two and the Democrats one. It is quite incorrect to claim that there will always be a 3-3 split in each state at a half Senate election. However, the point has been made that no party will ever get a majority of four senators out of six at a half-Senate election because 57 per cent of the vote is required and this is rarely achieved. I would agree with that, but let us fact the facts on this issue. With the exception of a short period, the presiding government has not had a majority for years. More often than not the government has needed the support of a minority party to help carry through its legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the arguments which have been put forward are barely worthy of reply. Both Senator Lewis and Senator Watson consider the legislation to be a devious plot by the Australian Labor Party so that it can remain in office for a long time while at the same time destroying the powers of the Senate. It is rather pointed that those two honourable senators were the final speakers for the Opposition when the Bill was debated a week last Friday. As I stated at the beginning of my speech, it was a pathetic time wasting exercise. Clearly, those two honourable senators ran out of legitimate arguments so we heard them sink again to anti-Labor party hysteria, which is typical of the type of speech on this legislation made by Mr Hodgman in the House of Representatives.

Of course, no debate is complete without a contribution from Senator Walters. One of the more inconsequential points she made was about her concern that the States of Victoria and New South Wales would still have more seats between them under the new legislation than the smaller States combined.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get it right; I said Victoria and New South Wales.

—Victoria and New South Wales. I thought I said that her concern was that the States of Victoria and New South Wales would still have more seats between them under the new legislation than the smaller States. This situation exists now and it is hardly surprising, considering the populations involved. Unfortunately, that is one of the prices we have to pay for living in a democracy. Obviously, Senator Walters was short of legitimate argument on the subject. She could not resist the opportunity to assist in filling up the speakers' list for the Opposition. What we have heard from Senator Archer today, Senator Watson the other day and Senator Walters and some others like her is that they just oppose change for change's sake. This legislation should be passed as quickly as possible. I wish it a speedy passage through the Senate.

—Mr Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented. Just in case anyone should believe what Senator Sibraa said in his interpretation of the point I made, I repeat that the record will show that it was the priority of the Government in the expenditure of that amount of money that I was querying. I made the point that the money would have been far better spent at a time like this on education or the Wynyard airport than on trying to improve our own luxury, comfort and convenience here. The second matter about which he was wrong was that I was making the point that this shambles of a paper that we have been given pretending to set out the cost is still totally unacceptable. He purported that I had asked for it and had received it. The point is that it does not cover at all the matters about which we were talking and we will still insist on that information being provided.

—Mr Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented. Senator Sibraa seems to take delight in misquoting the Opposition. Indeed, he told the Senate a few minutes ago that simultaneous elections would cost a lot more and claimed that my speech in which I said that the additional members of Parliament would increase the cost was at variance with my speech on the simultaneous elections legislation which would also cost more. In my speech on the simultaneous elections legislation, I maintained, and still do-it is accurate to say so-that there would be no need to have a referendum for simultaneous elections. The Government can, at any time it wants, hold simultaneous elections. No additional cost is needed. It can hold House of Representatives elections when Senate elections fall due. It is fallacious to say that, without a referendum agreeing to simultaneous elections, the cost for elections would be greater. Indeed, the situation is anything but. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall also be brief because I think all the arguments from both sides in relation to the Representation Bill have been effectively and carefully canvassed. There are valid arguments for and against the proposition. In my view, it is a question of subjectivity as to whether there ought to be more members of the House of Representatives and more senators servicing the community. I suppose, in many respects, it very much depends upon the perception that one has as a senator or as a member of the House of Representatives as to what one's functions ought to be and also what the community might expect of their members of parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I am fairly relaxed about increasing the size of the House of Representatives. I do not make any secret about drawing the conclusion that this legislation is clearly a cynical exercise by the Australian Labor Party which has made a judgment that the new boundaries are likely to advantage it. Frankly, if I were in its position and could see an alteration in boundaries advantaging me, I would look carefully at the same sort of exercise. I do not think anybody could question that, in the practical sense, if we had more members and senators we would all be more effective in our work. We would be able to service our electorates more effectively. I am sure the committee system would be much more effective and the individual party committee system would be much more effective . I think there is no question in the mind of any senator that, in the event that there were more of us, we would have more time to concentrate on debates in the chamber and upon the fine details of legislation. We would be able to examine and scrutinise it before it came before us.

The size of the Parliament has not been increased since 1949. At that time there was a population in Australia of about eight million; there is about 15.5 million people in Australia now. There has not been an increase in the size of Parliament since that time. One could assume that there were too many members then or too few now. I think the observation has been made by others that there have been significant increases in the size of every State parliament. I have not detected any great revulsion at those increases. The real difficulty for me is the effect that the increase in the size of the House of Representatives would have on the Senate because, of course, we all know that section 24 of the Constitution requires that the number of members of the House of Representatives should be, as near as practicable, twice the number of senators. Therefore, each State would return 12 senators and in each half Senate election six senators would returned.

It is my judgment-and I have looked at this matter very carefully and I think it is generally conceded-that, on the quotas we will find on the people becoming educated, on each occasion three Labor senators and three coalition senators will be returned and we will perpetually have a hung Senate with, perhaps, one Australian Democrat being elected from Victoria and one independent being elected from Tasmania. This will, in my view, bring the Senate into very considerable disrepute. The Senate will be in a permanent deadlock position with one or two people controlling the fate of the Government. The problem could be solved by further increasing the size of the Senate by 24 senators and by increasing the size of the House of Representatives by 48 members. That is not a position that I suspect anybody really supports.

The proposition has been put that that problem could be overcome by breaking the nexus between the Senate and the House of Representatives. I am totally opposed to that. Section 24 of the Constitution was a fundamental tenet of the Constitution at the time of its construction at the Sydney convention of 1897. The less populous States made it abundantly clear in their overwhelming vote in favour of that section that if there were to be no nexus and if there were to be no section 24 there would be no Constitution as we know it. On the other hand, if the Senate were to remain stagnant as a result of the breaking of the nexus and if the House of Representatives were to grow significantly in size, it is without question that the influence of the Senate would diminish. There would be inevitable pressure, as the House of Representatives grew, for the Senate to take a less aggressive and constructive role in respect of legislation that comes before it. It will be argued, of course, why 64 senators should be able to hold up legislation which had been passed by a house which has anything up to 200 members.

Of course, the breaking of the nexus would be devastating to the smaller States . As has been observed already, New South Wales and Victoria combined have more members of the House of Representatives than all the other States combined. In fact, there are more House of Representatives seats in outer metropolitan Sydney and Melbourne than there are in all of the smaller States combined. Such a proposal could, of course, only assist and be advantageous to the larger States at the expense of the smaller States. We would have a situation, of course, where, in the coalition parties room where we all have an equal voice, the smaller States would lose their influence. Of course, section 57 is intrinsically tied to section 24 of the Constitution. That was the second leg of the great debate. If we removed the nexus in respect of the implementation of section 57, of course, we would very signficantly diminish the capacity of the Senate to have a very real voice in breaking the deadlock. The Senate is the chamber in which the smaller States have an equal voice. If the value and strength of that voice were reduced or diminished so would the influence of the smaller States suffer. There would be no bulwark against the dominance of the larger States. We know that all governments spend money where there are votes. As there are more votes in New South Wales and Victoria, the smaller States would suffer more and more. Of course, as the influence of the Senate diminishes and the influence of the smaller States diminishes, the move will be on more and more to reduce the power of the Senate. I am sure that Senator Gareth Evans and his Government have made no secret about their ambition to reduce the capacity and the power of the Senate and the capacity and the power of the smaller States .

TALK.START.PARA: —Would that we could.

—That is what Senator Gareth Evans said before. I am very pleased to be able to quote that every time I am involved in a debate such as this. One has only to look at the recent diabolical prostitution of the external affairs powers to get the slightest idea of the long term ambitions that Senator Evans has to centralise all power in Canberra at the expense of the smaller States and to trample underfoot their capacity--
—We will give you permission to incorporate your paranoia.

—Coming from Victoria, of course, the honourable senator does not have paranoia. He is 55 minutes away from home by aeroplane. People who live in Sydney are 35 minutes away from home by aeroplane. Those of us who live in Western Australia can find themselves in the sort of situation I was in last night when I went to my federal executive meeting, got on an aeroplane at 11.45 p.m. and got here this morning at 9.45 in time for a party meeting. Honourable senators can understand why West Australians are opposed to centralism. Honourable senators can understand why the people in Canberra, Sydney and Melbourne have not the slightest idea of what the people in Western Australia are thinking; West Australians are very happy to be insulated. Honourable senators opposite are very glad to make all the diabolical decisions made here irrespective of the attitudes, views, wishes, ambitions and aspirations of the people in the smaller States.
—It has not impaired your performance.

—It has not impaired my performance? If one were to reduce the capacity of the Senate, one would certainly reduce the capacity of those who represent the smaller States. For the reasons that I have outlined, I am opposed to this legislation and I will vote against it.

SPEECH.PARA: I make just one further observation. I am inspired by the interjections by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). There has become a convention of wisdom and a view put in the Parliament that this legislation flows from the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. I quote the point made by Mr Young who was Special Minister of State that that exercise would have been better undertaken in isolation from the work that was being done by the Committee. It was never his intention or the intention of the Committee that this legislation or similar legislation, or consideration of such legislation, should flow from that inquiry .

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not intend to speak in this debate because I felt that the case of the National Party of Australia had been covered very well by Senators Scott and Collard, but I read in one of our local newspapers during the past week that I was leading the fight for the new members of parliament so I thought that perhaps I should place on record my situation in this regard. The National Party decided at a meeting some weeks ago that there was a need for more members in the House of Representatives in particular. It has been pointed out on many occasions in this debate that the population is now twice the size that it was in 1949, 34 years ago, the last occasion that there was an increase in the number of members of parliament. Lots of people say that we do not need any more members of parliament now. I wonder what people said 34 years ago when there was an increase in the representation in the Senate from 36 to 60 and the House of Representatives from 75 to 121. Looking back now, they must have thought that everybody was doing nothing. Now we have twice the population, twice the number of people to serve in Australia; yet people say that we do not now need any more members of parliament. In 1966 it was agreed that there should be more members of Parliament. The referendum Bill was passed but, because the nexus could not be broken, the referendum did not pass.

SPEECH.PARA: Many people say that there is a need for more members in the House of Representatives but that there is no need for more senators. At the rate that legislation is being put away to Senate committees these days, I am beginning to think that we do need more senators. I feel that soon there will not be enough senators to serve on all these committees. In fact sometimes it crosses my mind to ask what the Senate is here for, whether its purpose is to make decisions on legislation that comes to it or whether it is to put legislation away to Senate committees. I think we ought to do our job and try to make decisions in the Senate. We should be legislators and make up our minds in the Senate rather than always be putting legislation away to committees. That is one of the thoughts that come to me regarding this legislation.

If the Australian people feel that we do not need as many new members and senators as proposed, there is not much they can do about it at present because, when the proposal was put to them to break the nexus, they decided that they did not want to do so. In 1967 they had that opportunity. In order to get more members in the House of Representatives, it is necessary to increase the number of senators. Many people say to me: 'Why do you need more members of parliament? ' It is a constant cry and I presume that most honourable senators have the same amount of mail on this subject as I have.

It is quite obvious that we do need a redistribution in some shape or form. If there are no new members in the House of Representatives, the big electorates will get bigger. There is no doubt about that. I look at my State of Queensland where the seat of Kennedy, represented by Bob Katter Senior, is three times the size of Victoria. Victoria has 32 members to look after it, I think.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thirty-three.

—Thank you very much, Senator Ray. Honourable senators may say to me: 'Well, there are more people in Victoria'. I love to say that Victoria fits into Queensland seven times. Nevertheless, imagine one man trying to represent an area that is three times the size of Victoria.
—But he does it well.

—He certainly does it very well and so does Ian Cameron, the member for Maranoa, whose electorate is 2 1/2 times the size of Victoria. He uses a two-way radio to talk to his constituents. Many people say that there should be one vote one value. It comes up quite often. I do not agree with that philosophy and I never have. I know that it is Australian Labor Party policy. Some years ago the 20 per cent tolerance for country areas was reduced to 10 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: I feel that consideration needs to be given to the people of the country parts of Australia who live so far out and who help to bring in our export earnings. That is one reason why I do not want to see the large electorates get larger. It makes it very much harder for people who live in rural outback parts of Australia to see their member. If one lives in a city electorate one can catch a bus-one cannot catch a tram in Brisbane any more, unfortunately-or one can phone one's member for the price of a local phone call. Those who live in the outback have to make a trunk call. If they want to see their member, it could possibly take them two days to travel by car. Maybe if one was a long distance runner like Ron Grant, the Caboolture baker, one might be able to run to get there.

Certainly I agree that the decision which is being made in the Senate and which has been made in the House of Representatives, to increase the number of members of parliament, is not a very popular one. It never will be. Whenever one mentions more members of parliament it is like a red rag to a bull. People do not like to think about the need for more members of parliament.

I feel that over the last number of redistributions, without any more seats, the quality of country representation has diminished. There is no doubt about that. If we do not have more members of parliament now, in 1988 when we go into a larger and bigger Parliament House, will that be the right time? I must admit that it might be a bit hard to fit everybody in the present Parliament House. When will be the right time? It never will be the right time to have more members of parliament. I am sure that is what people say. I wonder why people hate members of parliament so much. Do they think that we do not do any work? I do not know why they think we do not do any work. I have been very busy from the time I left here the week before last until I came back. We are always busy in here. Do people get a bad impression of members of parliament when they listen to the radio? I do not know how many times I have made speeches in different areas of Queensland and asked people whether they had heard me make speeches on the radio. On one occasion I thought that I was making a fine speech in here and that everybody was listening with bated breath to what I had to say on the radio . I spoke at half a dozen meetings and not one person had been listening to the broadcasting of parliament on the radio. They would rather listen to sweet music . Maybe that is why people do not like members of parliament. Maybe they say: ' They will cost too much'. The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has told us today how the cost of the extra members has been estimated.

There was also a proposition that, instead of having more members of parliament , perhaps we should have more staff. To me there is not much difference in cost, although I suppose that it is in millions of dollars and it is a lot of money. But there is not much difference between the cost of staff and the cost of members of parliament. However, my attitude is that the people one represents want to see their member of parliament, rather than one of the staff. That is another important point that should be considered. Another aspect is that, if we increase members' staff or increase public servants, such people do not go to the electors. At least the electors have a chance to say whether or not they want a particular politician, and all members of parliament hope that they are wanted and will not be put out of a job at the next election. I feel that if we give good service, so that people feel that we earn our salaries and respect us, perhaps they might not complain so much about the cost. Those are just some of the points that I wanted to raise. As a National Party member, I shall be supporting this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the amendment moved by Senator Jack Evans to insert the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: this Bill be not further proceeded with until such time as the Constitution Alteration (Parliament) Bill 1983, which was passed by an absolute majority of the Senate on 18 October 1983, is submitted to the people pursuant to section 128 of the Constitution.

The debate in the community and in this place has revolved around a number of matters, one of which is the appropriateness of breaking the nexus to enable the House of Representatives to be increased at appropriate times by the amounts which seem appropriate at those times without affecting numbers in the Senate. A Bill that went through the Senate to break the nexus would allow the House of Representatives to be increased at this time. It would also allow for the fact that at some appropriate time in the future the Senate would be able to be increased by four members for each State, as would be appropriate to maintain the situation of uneven numbers at half Senate elections.

The National Party of Australia, in its justification for its stance in supporting this Bill, has said that it would prefer that the nexus be broken. Its preferred position would be that this Bill be put to the people first by way of a referendum, so that the people could say whether the nexus should be broken . I therefore would imagine that the National Party would support this amendment to enable that precise operation to happen. The electorate is already faced with a number of referendum questions to be put on 25 February next year. This amendment would give the people an opportunity of saying first whether they wished that nexus to be broken so that no longer would we need absurd increases when an increase was desirable. As I said at the second reading stage, the Australian Democrats support a modest increase in the House of Representatives at present-a modest increase, nowhere near the increase currently projected. The facts of the matter are that the minimum number for an increase in the Senate is two for each State or 12 in all, which means an increase of 24 in the House of Representatives. Our amendment would enable us to see whether the people wished, first, to break the nexus. Interestingly enough, breaking the nexus has the support of every political party in this country.

Mr Anthony, as Leader of the National Party, has made no bones about the fact that this is his preferred position. He is not here, but the representatives of the National Party are here and I would imagine that they would support their leader on this matter, so that the people can say whether they want the nexus broken. If the National Party votes against this, the situation is not what it has been stating in the electorate by way of Press releases. It is very clear that the reason why National Party senators are voting for this Bill in the Senate is precisely that people in the House of Representatives have asked them to do so.

If our amendment were accepted, it would delay the Bill. It would not defeat the Bill. When the House of Representatives and the Senate assembled in the autumn session, if the people had decided not to break the nexus, the National Party and the Australian Labor Party would be able to support the Bill and to have it passed. It is a delaying mechanism. It is not a defeat for the Bill. Regardless of whether or not senators believe that the nexus should be broken, I am sure that all senators believe that the nexus question should be put to the people for their deliberation. It will, in fact, be the only vote of any kind by which the people can express their views about the increase in the size of the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last minute rhetorical flurries by Ministers in reply rarely have much relevance or utility so far as changing anybody's mind is concerned, even given the abundance of free floating spirits in this place. But a Minister's reply seems to have less relevance than ever in the context of a debate like this, given the intense interest and scrutiny which the Representation Bill 1983 has generated and received by all parties from their respective points of view; so I will confine myself to a bald and exceedingly brief recitation of the basic planks in the Government's argument.

SPEECH.PARA: First, the Bill will reduce the ludicrous situation whereby the population of the nation has doubled since 1949 but the composition of the Federal parliamentary representatives remains the same, placing an impossible burden on the servicing of constituencies. The second point is that the Bill and the increase achieved by it will enable the parliamentary committee system to be serviced properly in a way that has become really quite impossible with the multiplicity of tasks Parliament is now performing, such as legislative review, policy development, Executive oversight and Executive monitoring, most of which were not tasks regarded as appropriate for parliamentarians in times gone past. The argument is equally strong in relation to the Senate, even though there has been some resistance to that concept; the best demonstration of that being the debate we had in the last week we were here about the servicing or membership of the proposed select committee on animal welfare. There was sympathy all round the chamber, and particularly on the Government side, for the notion that there should be greater representation than four members on that committee but there was agreement around the chamber that it was simply impossible for that target to be met given the shortage of senators and the other competing burdens.

The third argument is that the change will restore a healthier relationship between the Executive and the legislature. With a growth in the size of the Ministry, particularly if assistant Ministers are to be appointed, there is an imbalance between Government and back benchers, whichever party is in power, and the health of the system will be substantially improved were that balance to be reshaped in the way now proposed.

The fourth point is that the Bill will in fact increase the talent pool from which Ministers can be appointed or chosen, again whichever party is in power. I do not concede of course that there have been any deficiencies in the particular fish which have been plucked from the present Caucus pool to constitute the present Ministry, but it is nonetheless an argument of reasonable weight and substance.

The final point, and one that has been made by numerous honourable senators, is that there is never a right time to increase the number of politicians, but this is as close to it as we are ever going to get. We are in the process of updating and consolidating the electoral legislation and we are of course preparing to move into a new Parliament House at a point now in the building program where this increase and the resultant extensions can be accommodated with minimum additional cost.

I turn to the Australian Democrats' amendment. The point about the nexus has been made on numerous occasions and it does not need to be treated at length. The cost saving that would be involved in having the proposed additional number of House of Representatives members, but not the senators on this occasion, would in fact be minimal. If honourable senators do the arithmetic that people will apparently be wanting to do in the Committee of the Whole, they will see that we will still have to pay out two-thirds of the cost of $6.18m. That is the recurring annual costs for members and senators. We will of course still have to pay out the whole of the $3.17m, that is the payout associated with the 23 divisional officers. So instead of paying $9m a year we will be paying only $7m- a huge saving! On the cost side, the nexus argument demonstrates its inconsequentiality rather rapidly. The other argument of course is the one made on numerous occasions about the difficulty at this stage of running a sixth question with the 25 February referendums. Whatever the intrinsic merits of the breaking of the nexus proposal might be for the longer term-and I have indicated that the Government certainly has not abandoned the idea of running a referendum on that issue at some appropriate time in the future, perhaps at the time of the next election-it is extremely inappropriate to do so in the context of the 25 February referendums adding as it would another very divisive question to the paper and making very much more complex the process of both explaining to voters what it is about and attracting their support. So for those reasons the nexus referendum proposal, as a precondition of an increase of the kind here, is not accepted. Mr Deputy President, the case for an increase in the size of the Parliament is very strong indeed. It has been amply articulated by speakers from various parts of the House and I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Amendment negatived.

Also in the Bill are transition clauses relating to a double dissolution. In debate on the second reading of the Bill, Senator Teague, in particular, raised matters dealing with the transition clauses. It was an interesting speech, mainly because Senator Teague seemed to be unaware that there are two sets of transition clauses. The main thrust of his argument related to the Australian Democrats. The argument went basically that overall the Democrats would get more members elected under the new proposals, but we should be worried about the transition clauses, and that this was our real reason for opposing the Bill. This is in connection with an additional 12 senators and 23 members of the House of Representatives, a total of 35 people, working out at $47,777 per--
—Two staff for each, divide by two.

—I recognise that the Attorney-General is a lawyer and not a mathematician, so I hope that he refers these matters to someone on his staff who will be able to apply a mathematical, instead of a legal, mind to them. TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Chairman. However, when one does the same calculation for 189 members, taking first of all the research assistant salary level, which presumably would be the salary for additional staff, one comes up with a factor of $3,279,000 which falls so far short of $6.2m as to suggest that a different basis was used. Possibly the basis of $19,000 might have been used, but that still does not work . Indeed, the motion of lumping in travel as though travel were calculated at the same rate is to suggest something that has not been suggested, and that is that travel entitlements would also be expanded.

The point I wish to make is not so much one in relation to the costs in the Bill but rather the way that the statement has been put together, the lack of detail in the statement and the lack of precision in the statement so that it is possible for senators actually to know the assumptions that have been made when various calculations are presented. For example, I believe it would have been far better under item 4, which relates to staff salaries, allowances and travel, simply to detail what might have been the assumptions, whether the calculations were based on an amount of $17,000 and $19,000, whether or not the allowances or overtime were calculated at 20 per cent of the normal salary rate and whether or not travel was calculated on some other basis. If this were done I think we would be able to have confidence that we were comparing like with like and that would promote a reasonable debate in the community. I think the fact that these figures have been presented in such a bald way, in a way which does not go into this type of detail, merely adds to the confusion of the debate in the community .

I admit that it is better for the Government to give as few details as possible , thereby not provoking any more disquiet in the community. I note that the total estimated amount miraculously was managed to be kept below $10m, which is a useful figure. I admit those things. Nevertheless, in the long term I believe it is important that any financial impact statement should spell out those details and the assumptions that are made by governments in what must admittedly be an area of assumptions. One cannot be firm about many of these things because they are simply estimates. However, it would be useful to have the assumptions upon which those estimates were made.

I do not know whether Senator Macklin wants to change the double dissolution system. —It has never occurred and what the honourable senator postulates will probably never occur either. All that one can say is that one can disprove every assertion that has been made in this place by looking at past figures. The one thing one cannot do is predict what the future will be. It is just impossible to do that. We have already had that same theoretical possibility in the double dissolutions of 1974, 1975 and 1983 when 10 senators from each State were elected.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point I wish to raise relates to the financial impact statement made by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). Have any calculations been done in regard to the claw-back value to the Government, especially in terms of the rate of tax that politicians pay? How much does the Government get back? I will say this only once because I do not think it would help proceedings here if we got into a protracted argument. He is possibly right. I would have imagined that what would have happened in the normal course of events was that the Democrats were eliminated and maybe 0.2 of a quota would have gone to both the major parties; leaving the Liberals with 2.7 and Labor with 2.8, with the remaining 0.5 to be distributed at a far greater rate to the Liberal Party than the Labor Party. TALK.START.PARA: —You can do it by fiddling the territorial representation.

—If Senator Misssen read the House of Representatives debate on this subject he would find that it was put by Mr Wilson that in fact this Government should look at that question through the continuing inquiry of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. The Government will do that. What the Special Minister of State (Mr Beazley) could not have known was that we discussed this on the Committee. We unanimously agreed that no one wants the territorial representation fiddled and that legislation should be introduced. It is probably not an urgent matter. If we are not intending to do it in the next six months we can bring in that Bill some time next year when we have investigated it. I do not think territorial representation will be fiddled. No one really knows. One could start fiddling the territorial representation but no one knows what the final position would be. I will not go much further. Senator Teague has made projections about what the past results mean and so have I. They are remarkly common in fact. We may differ over one or two States. The basic thrust of the matter is that it is unlikely that in a half Senate election, no matter whether for six senators or five senators, one party will be the majority party. —This might be an appropriate stage to ask the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) to clarify a couple of points about clause 5 of the Bill. It is a brief Bill. Clause 5 is the main clause on the second page. Clause 5 is to try to cope with the election of seven senators, six of whom will be long term senators and one of whom, I take it, will be a short term senator. That is the problem. Under clause 5 (4) the senator last elected is to be a short term senator in effect. In clause 5 (3) special arrangements are made for the two non-sitting senators. If the Attorney says to me that the words 'subject to sub-section (4)' mean that the person would in fact be a short term senator and that only one non-sitting senator would be long term, that is fine; but then the question arises: Why was it necessary to put in the second part of clause 5 (3)? It really serves no useful purpose. In fact, the only purpose that clause 5 (3) seems to serve is to say that the newly elected senators will have six-year terms, but they would have that anyway. SPEECH.PARA: Two other groups of matters were raised by honourable senators in contributions to the Committee debate. One group of matters related to discussions about the arithmetic of the Bill and projections as to who would benefit and who would not . These contributions largely took the form of either swapping intuitions or waging private warfare, or both. I am referring in particular to the first speech of Senator Macklin. Senator Teague at one point was also waging war, I think, on his contribution to the debate on the second reading. I point out to Senator Robert Ray that I do not think there is anything really useful I can contribute to that debate, which has been a long one within the party room so far and which will no doubt continue to be a long debate because it is simply a matter of best guessing, I think. It does not affect, in any event, the drafting of this legislation.

The other group of matters that were raised dealt with the cost projections involved in the financial impact statement. As to the costs concerning the new Parliament House, I simply am not in a position to advise the Committee what the cost of the extensions to the building as presently designed would be because it has not yet been calculated. It will be something in excess of $10m. We know that. How much in excess and what precisely that will be we are not able to say. If we had been able to indicate the cost we would have done so in the statement. It is premature to say at this stage. The architects and the quantity surveyors are still working and the cost estimates are still being done.

As to the detail of the statement, most of the fuss seemed to concentrate on claims, pressed with varying degrees of vigour, about the implausibility of the figures shown at page 2 of the statement. I indicate the assumptions on which those figures were based in order, I hope, to satisfy Senator Macklin and, indeed, Senator Lewis. The estimated $1.72m for staff salaries, allowances and travel as a component of the cost of the additional 35 members and senators is made up as follows: Staff salaries, 35 multiplied by two multiplied by an average of $20,000 comes to a total of $1.4m. It may be that that average of $20 ,000 is pitching things a little high in terms of what the salary rates are at the moment, but there is not a massive variation created by that particular difference. That comes to $1.4m. Relief, at a ratio currently applicable all through the Public Service, calculated at 1 : 7, comes to $0.1m. Overtime is calculated at $0.1m, and travel at $0.12m. That makes a total of $1.72m for salaries, relief, overtime and travel. The estimated $6.2m for providing an additional staff member for the existing 189 members and senators is made up as follows: 189 times $18,500. If anything, the assumptions are down. If we wanted to really beef up the rhetorical point that was being made we would have made that $20,000 to match the earlier figure. The idea essentially is that the third member of staff may well be a junior steno-typist and the salary rate basically could be expected to average out at a lower per head cost than for making up the quota of staff for the new appointees. For salaries the figure of 189 is multiplied by $18,500, which comes to $3.5m. Relief, at the same 1 : 7 ratio, is $0.5m. Overtime is $0.5m. Travel is $1.4m, based on essentially the same assumptions as the $0.12m figure in the first table. Office requisites, including telephones, stationery and so on, were not, of course, in the first table because they were part of sub-item 3 rather than having to be built in in this way. The telephone costs of the different new staff members do add up, particularly if they have access to subscriber trunk dialling and so on. An amount of $0.3m is allocated for that, making a total of $6.2m.

Honourable senators could quibble about each one of those items but the end result would be a variation of not much more than about half a million dollars either way on the figures as they have been given. With all due respect to Senator Macklin, I do not believe that the debate either in the community or in this Parliament will be radically affected by differences of that order of magnitude. These figures were constructed on a quick rule of thumb basis but by reference to honestly applied criteria of the kind I have just articulated. It may be that, were a more detailed exercise to be done, we would get taken into account clawback factors of the kind that were mentioned by Senator Robert Ray. It may be that we would be able to take into account some reduced accommodation costs of the kind mentioned, for example, by Senator Missen. That will not help us much with the House of Representatives members but it certainly may be a great utility to be able to rely on existing vacant space in the Customs House in Melbourne and elsewhere for honourable senators.

These are other factors which, in a really detailed exercise, will undoubtedly go into the equation. I repeat that I do not believe any of these variations is likely to affect the basic substance of the argument. I hope honourable senators will regard these figures accordingly as having been given in good faith in order to meet a perfectly understandable and legitimate demand for information.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) that I accept the figures in the way that he has given them to us. I am delighted to accept his assessment that half a million dollars one way or the other would probably be fair enough. I must say that the travel item of $1.4m for an additional staff member is of great concern to me but I understand the problem. —Maybe it includes the building as well. I repeat that the figure of $17,500, when multiplied by 189 is $3.31m. —The reason we started probing into these figures was that we received an undertaking from the Minister for Finance ( Senator Walsh) early in September that cost impact statements would be provided. —I will draw Senator Archer's remarks to the attention of the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) and the Special Minister of State (Mr Beazley), who bears immediate managerial responsibility for this area, in the hope that they will be duly chastened by the force of Senator Archer's indignation.
